146065549.review:
I just finished my playthrough of the game again after almost 10 years of inactivity and I have to say, it is still as good as when I remembered. 

The game is basically 13 years old by now, and it is a leap from the first Mass Effect game in terms of length and characters. Here is my honest opinion:

The game itself stand-alone is great but to get the true experience you need to import a ME1 character and play the full Paragon or Renegade route. The amount of nods to the actions from the first game always gives me a smile. The crew is much larger and diverse, and my husbando Garrus is as good as ever.

Exploring every planet and quest is easily a 20+ hour experience, and DLC from the remastered version adds more you want. 

Combat-wise, I have mixed feelings. The number of health bars and ways to counter each makes combat more than just "shoot the bad guy", however, on the higher difficulty it is a slog sometimes, especially since some powers don't work on certain bars (So team composition is important). The thermal clip mechanic is annoying, and the vent version form ME1 is better. As for the powers, the amount is strongly reduced and ALL abilities go on cooldown once you use one (the time depending on the ability). It forces you to use your guns more often.

The best thing they added was the amount of in-depth characterization they put into the teammates.  Each has a story to tell, their own history and you can explore them together. The loyalty missions is the icing on the cake.

Are there bugs like Audio missing, weird camera angles in cutscenes, stuck camera while charging, glitchy UI in the combat mode......? Yes, but it is rare and minor enough that it rarely disrupts combat. Most I blame on "modern computers running old games". 

TL;DR, ME2 is a great game full of character and a decent combat loop worth the investment.

142859543.review:
This is the strongest entry in the Mass Effect franchise and, ultimately, Bioware's ouvre. The first and foremost detail I'd note about this game is that the combat is a huge improvement over the original Mass Effect. Character build decisions have been refined down to only the impactful decisions; no more balancing of hundreds of skill points. The levels are much denser and better designed, and the enemies are, largely, much more interesting to fight. The shooting and cover systems are much more fluid. The original game feels janky in comparison.

Story-wise, there are more companion characters and they are much more fleshed out than the original's companions. Given that strong companion systems are what separate Bioware RPGs from other RPGs, this is an enormous plus. I'd also say that the quest stories have much more lively characters involved, and there are generally more twists and intrigue. However, the main story is about on par with the original. 

So, the game is good! Worth playing, and the entire trilogy is also worth playing. It's probably worth picking up Mass Effect Legendary Edition rather than this version so as to enjoy the entire series in its most up-to-date form.

Note: I played and beat this game on console several years ago. I haven't played this PC version for much time at all.

Kiba Snowpaw, a hardened Ice Wolf and experienced gamer of 36 years, stared steadily at his computer screen with purpose. This was no ordinary game - it was a mission across the vastness of the universe, a thrilling journey that could bring hope to the gaming world. He knew that this challenge was going to be greater than anything He had ever faced before. However, Kiba was ready for what awaited him in Mass Effect 2, even if He still felt a chill of fear in his heart as He launched the PC version on Steam 🐺❄️🎮

When it comes to gaming, I'm no amateur - having been a longtime aficionado of indie gems and an avid follower of anime, manga, and movies since the 80s. My mind raced with excitement as I flipped through the glowing review of Mass Effect 2's brilliance. Yet despite the promise of something truly extraordinary, my heart revolted against the idea of leaving behind my treasured classics. A tug of war between two vastly different worlds was raging in my soul.

As I stepped into the mesmerizing world of Mass Effect 2, I felt a shiver go down my spine. I was completely captivated by the stunning visuals, enthralled by the captivating soundtracks and spellbound by the complex gameplay mechanics which put me on constant edge. It was unlike anything I had encountered before; an alternate universe where every decision had consequences, and every mission was ripe with adventure that filled me with exhilaration. The storyline was unravelling in front of me like a stunning tapestry, and the personalities of the characters seemed to deepen as I progressed forward. As the game made its way onto PC shortly afterwards, conflicting emotions erupted within me - elation at discovering this universe belonged more than just one platform, fear at having to explore it all over again.

The biting cold of the Arctic wind stung at the Ice Wolf's fur as he pressed forward on his journey, yet at the same time, a glimmer of hope shone in his eyes. Mass Effect 2 was calling to him, an oasis amidst the desolate tundra that promised captivating drama, thrilling action, and side-splitting comedy. Despite his excitement, he felt an overwhelming sense of dread as he pondered dark secrets that lay hidden within the plot. The characters were so full of life and emotion that they made his frozen heart ache, but their bonds also provided warmth and comfort that not even the Fire Wolf could match. 🔥❄️

Mass Effect 2 ornaments the gaming landscape like a dazzling snow globe. It envelops you in its unique and spectacular combination of third-person shooter mechanics, RPG elements, and captivating storytelling, while leaving other games in its wake. The RPG elements may be simplified and occasionally limiting, but this isn't an RPG; it's a universe teeming with meaningful decisions and stories that penetrate even the coldest of hearts.

But even the harshest winter has its spring, and Mass Effect 2 is no exception. The Deluxe Edition on Steam does not include the significant expansions such as "Lair of the Shadow Broker," "The Arrival," and "Stolen Dreams." This left a frosty taste in my mouth, as I felt deceived by EA's icy business practices. There's a special place in the Arctic for companies that mislead their players, and EA is inching ever closer to it.

Gameplay in Mass Effect 2 is like a snowstorm; it's fast, relentless, and unpredictable. It blends RPG elements with a cover shooter, creating a unique gaming experience that sends chills down your spine. And let's not forget about the class-specific abilities and weapons, which add a touch of frosty freshness to every playthrough. It's like an avalanche of action and strategy that keeps you on your toes.

Evaluating Mass Effect 2 is like trying to hold onto an icicle: it's tricky, and you'll probably get a cold shock, but the result is a beautiful and fragile work of art. The main strength of the game lies in its narrative and characters, which are as cold and unforgiving as they are warm and comforting. The story is a blizzard of emotions that chills you to the bone, and the choices you make feel as if they hold the weight of the entire galaxy.

But the game's shortcomings are also as clear as ice. The lack of DLCs in the Deluxe Edition and the hoops you have to jump through to access the extras is like stepping on a patch of black ice: unexpected, unpleasant, and unnecessary.

Despite these minor cracks, Mass Effect 2 remains a beautiful ice sculpture in the winter of gaming. It's a must-play, a testament to the narrative power of video games, and a shining gem in the frosty wilderness.

Remember, even the coldest tundra has its warmth, and even the darkest night has its dawn. Stay frosty, my friends. 🌙❄️💙

I am utterly captivated by Mass Effect 2 (2010 Edition), a game that has truly withstood the test of time and remains an absolute gem within the gaming industry. From the very moment I embarked on Commander Shepard's interstellar adventure, I was drawn into a world teeming with unforgettable characters, breathtaking visuals, and a gripping narrative that has set new standards for the sci-fi genre.

Graphically, Mass Effect 2 (2010 Edition) still stands tall even in today's era of advanced gaming technology. The meticulously crafted environments, from the sprawling metropolis of Omega to the haunting beauty of Illium, leave players in awe of the game's attention to detail. Each planet, spaceship, and alien species is meticulously designed, immersing players into a universe that feels alive and authentic.

The heart of Mass Effect 2 lies within its rich and diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique personalities, backgrounds, and motivations. The game effortlessly weaves intricate narratives and compelling subplots for each companion, enabling players to form deep connections and forge friendships that transcend the virtual world. The depth of the character development in this game is unparalleled, with unforgettable moments of joy, camaraderie, and heartbreak that will leave players emotionally invested until the very end.

The gameplay mechanics of Mass Effect 2 (2010 Edition) are flawlessly executed, striking the perfect balance between thrilling combat and strategic decision-making. The refined third-person shooter mechanics offer exhilarating firefights, complemented by a vast array of powerful weapons and abilities that allow players to customize their playstyle. Furthermore, the game's robust dialogue system and morality-based choices provide a truly personalized experience, granting players the freedom to shape the destiny of the galaxy and face the consequences of their actions.

Additionally, the hauntingly beautiful musical score, composed by the legendary Jack Wall, adds another layer of depth to the game's atmosphere. The melodic tunes perfectly capture the essence of each scene, whether it's the pulse-pounding excitement of a space battle or the quiet introspection during heartfelt conversations. The voice acting is equally superb, with performances that breathe life into the characters, making every interaction a memorable experience.

Mass Effect 2 (2010 Edition) is an epic space odyssey that transcends its time and remains a masterpiece in gaming. Its gripping narrative, unforgettable characters, stunning visuals, and exceptional gameplay mechanics make it a true contender for the title of one of the greatest games ever created. Whether you're a fan of sci-fi or simply appreciate a brilliantly crafted game, Mass Effect 2 (2010 Edition) is an absolute must-play that will leave you yearning for more.

Steam users, prepare to embark on an unforgettable journey through the cosmos and experience the brilliance of Mass Effect 2 (2010 Edition). Strap in, Commander Shepard, and get ready to shape the fate of the galaxy like never before.

138509257.review:
I finished the game in little under 30 hours, which means main story and quite a few side mission but not all of them.
It's mainly a shooter game with some added layers. The environments in which you play are diverse as are the enemies that you encounter. You can find/buy upgrades for armor and weaponry along the way.  Resources to research these upgrades are also found along the way or by harvesting planets. I mainly used three weapons: SMG, rocket launcher and sniper rifle and wouldn't advise to invest in the others. Also: use advanced training to add new powers to Shepard's portfolio.
Intergalactic currency is plentiful. Hacking consoles is easy.
I personally didn't like the endless conversations although these can be skipped.
You put some effort in gathering members for your squad (spoiler: that drop like flies in the final mission lol). Using the powers of the squad members is fun but it happened to me quite often that their powers were just regenerating when I needed them most.
Fighting the end boss was rather easy (it took me only one try).
The atmosphere made me sometimes think: "Deus Ex in space". All in all certainly not bad for a game released in 2010 and still quite playable in 2023.

My favorite game in the series. Less RPG mechanics, but much better gameplay than ME1 which even 13 years later doesn't really feel outdated, good tradeoff imo. Story and Dialogue are fantastic, altough I can understand that some people might find large parts of the ME2 plot unnecessary for the overall Trillogy. It's still great for what it is and introduces many interesting and memorable characters. Overall ME2 is a real treat to play everytime I'm going through the series and I can't recommend it enough. You should absolutely play ME1 first though, you can even import your final save of the previous game so that many important decisions will carry over.

In my opinion the Trillogy is still a must play for everyone even remotely interested in Sci-Fi, RPGs or both. But I would highly recommend playing it via the Legendary Collection instead since it includes all DLC (which are mostly great) and noticeably improved visuals.

136017822.review:
Mass Effect 2? More like Mass Effect Too Good To Be True! This game is a space opera of epic proportions that will have you blasting aliens, romancing your crew, and making choices that could literally save the galaxy. But let's be real, we all know the real draw of Mass Effect 2: the facial animations.

Who needs realistic dialogue and nuanced storytelling when you can have Shepard's deadpan stare as they deliver lines like "I should go" with all the emotion of a rock? And don't even get me started on the awkward lip syncing. I mean, it's like watching a bad Japanese dub of a B-movie. But hey, at least it's hilarious, right?

But in all seriousness, Mass Effect 2 is a fantastic game. The loyalty missions are a great way to deepen your relationships with your crew members, and the combat system is a blast. Plus, who doesn't love the feeling of commanding their own spaceship and exploring the vast reaches of the galaxy?

So if you're looking for a game that combines action, romance, and unintentional comedy, then look no further than Mass Effect 2. It's like a space soap opera with all the cheesy dialogue and over-the-top drama you could ever want.

131805142.review:
Three years ago I started my second playthrough of the Mass Effect Series with ME1. Today I reached the end of ME2. 

There were times, sure, when I found myself a little bored with the samey combat. There were moments of fatigue with some of the wordier dialogue. The planet scanning mini-task made me want to pull my hair out. Accidentally taking cover when I wanted to spring was irritating. And yes, I became annoyed at not being able to fill my renegade bar high enough to secure a certain character for my group. 

But through it all I could sense just enough soul in the DNA of ME2. Vibrant life in the fascinating worlds I visited. Interest in the story lines and diverse cast of characters that each were given time to develop. I grew to appreciate the renegade choices a lot more this time around. I understood the politics behind the Illusive Man now that I have more context as an adult. And I even appreciated that the game was made in a time when women were allowed to look hot in games. 

Speaking of hot, I surprisingly found myself rather attracted to Jack more so for her personality, which was strange because I remembered really disliking her in my first playthrough as a teen. I think her story was quite interesting and had the potential to be its own game all on its own if someone wanted to make that. I only wish that after growing so close to her when she unfortunately met her demise, my Sheppard didn't seem terribly saddened or disturbed. I would've appreciated at least a sentence or two on losing his lover. 

And now I can finally play ME3 for the first time once they finally give us a discount on the damn game. 

So yes. Recommend.

130045049.review:
The companion quests and their stories are great, but the rest is really 'meh' and boring. The main story is full of frustrating plot holes, and the loyalty mechanic (the only bit that links the interesting stuff to the main plot) feels super arbitrary and disconnected. Preparing for the suicide mission feels less like a rallying of troops and more like solving an equation. Additionally, as soon as you complete a companion's loyalty mission, they stop doing or reacting to anything interesting and basically become a part of the Normandy's set dressing.

The dialogue is well-written, but is terrible from a role-playing perspective. You basically have five options: progress the conversation; progress the conversion while being a dick about it; ask about more information; and occasionally a special paragon or renegade option. The split between paragon and renegade is consistently frustrating and unpredictable. I wish they ditched the system and used an influence system instead (like in Fallout: New Vegas). Making the system worse is that you often need to meet a high threshold of paragon and renegade points to unlock certain options in dialogue, meaning you have to go all in on one to unlock those options, which reduces your ability to role-play and mix options. It also seems really artificial: why do need a certain number of dickhead points to be a dickhead in a different situation?

Finally, there are far too many annoying mini-games unbefitting for a space opera protagonist. Obviously, there is the planet scanning game, which you have to complete if you want to research upgrades. But there are also tedious vehicle sections and long hacking mini-games. The hacking mini-games are the worst, as they interrupt combat sections.

PS: the port sucks and requires you to sign up for EA nonsense to play the DLC.

129627014.review:
The first Mass Effect was a monumental game in the Star Trek simulator genre, the sequel removed all that was mediocre in that game and managed to conceive an even stronger storyline while still lacking Jean-Luc Picard.. The story takes on where the first game ends with a certain twist. You are once again dressed up as Commander Shepard in this narrative RPG adventure with some gunplay and resource management shoehorned in for the sake of it. The talent tree is greatly reduced and even though you still find the classes from the first game the rudimentary skills makes the leveling much more convinient and the gameplay as a whole a bit more streamlined. Gone is the constant micromanaging of your squad in favor of a more action oriented shooting gallery style gameplay. The enemies are still stupid beyond belief but the sheer amount of health and ablative armor they have on the higher difficulty can still make you weep blood. 

Taking off from the rather grounded story in the first game that ended in a rather climactic revelation ME2 ups the ante a lot by having a far bigger scope. Most of the choices you made during the first installment will come back to haunt you and even impact your looks to a certain degree. The game starts with a twist and shortly after an encounter with a mysterious shadow cabal that pushes your squad of badass space mercenaries into action yet again. On your romp through the galaxy you encounter old friends and enemies as well as a whole bunch of new intriguing characters and locales. Without further spoiling anything the storytelling is tight as ever and the choices from the first game truly feel meaningful. Mass Effect 2 is a superior game to its predecessor and much like The Witcher series the gameplay between the first game and its sequel are so different that they could easily have been different games. In the end this is an epic experience of great storytelling coupled with satisfying gameplay and a great list of intriguing and likable characters. 

There is an argument that you could start up with ME2 right away, and I get it. But half of the thing that makes this game click for me is the legacy. What I did in the first game actually meant something down the line and I truly love that way of tying the storylines together. ME2 is a masterpiece and a definite cinematic gameplay experience. If you have any love whatsoever for Sci-fi this game is a must play, and even if you hate sci-fi, the story is compelling enough to lure the most blackhearted visual novel romantic into its grasp..

128064322.review:
A neutral review for the Steam version would be ideal but oh well what can you do.

The first three Mass Effect Games are fantastic and I highly recommend them to anyone who wants to give them a try, but I don't recommend buying the Steam version of the originals (other than maybe Mass Effect 3 if you want to play the multiplayer). You can play the games without a problem initially, but to access the DLC you're going to have to jump through quite a few hoops and out of the three games Mass Effect 2 gave me the most issues. Unsurprisingly if you got the game on Origin all the DLC is included with the base game so you won't have any of these issues. so it just feels like EA and/or BioWare is punishing players for buying this on Steam instead of Origin.

The DLC is free which is nice but it's not on Steam. You can get it to work but you have to google on how to access it as when I tried to download the DLC on Origin once the game showed up in that library, the game no longer launched so I had to uninstall and re-install a couple times. Eventually I found out you have to go to an external EA website and download the DLC's manually and as far as I can tell it works so you technically don't need Origin, but you will still need an EA account. It's just a lot bigger of a hassle than it needs to be.

I'm currently moving from console to PC so I tried to save a couple of bucks getting the trilogy on sale, as well as with the Legendary Edition as great as it is there is just something about it that I just like the atmosphere and lighting of the originals but that's just a personal preference. 

Overall for how much of a hassle it has been to get these games to work for me, the few nitpicks I have Legendary Edition I would highly recommend getting that instead unless you're just looking to complete your collection, as there are a lot more improvements and quality of life changes that make the game a lot better to play.

Mass Effect 2 9/10
Mass Effect 2 on Steam 6/10

127907118.review:
NOTA: 9.25 de 10

Aunque el primer Mass Effect fue un tesoro, esta segunda parte es para mí la mejor de la saga. Ciertos aspectos están más pulidos, como los gráficos, animaciones, efectos especiales, música, detalle en los mapas, siendo lo más destacable la gran cantidad de personajes que han introducido, con sus respectivos trasfondos, generando una gran variedad de alternativas y diferentes caminos por donde llegar a distintos finales. En este sentido es bastante rejugable.

También hay cosas que empeoran o se mantienen igual:

- Se echa en falta de Mass Effect 1 las granadas y su variedad de estrategias en los enemigos.

- La historia principal del personaje protagonista es demasiado rocambolesca y difícil de tragar. Las misiones y minijuegos son en algunos casos bastante cansinos. 

- El sistema de curación pasa ilógicamente de los botiquines en Mass Effect 1, a la regeneración tras cobertura en Mass Effect 2. Por lo general me dan bastante asco los juegos con regeneración troll, porque se hacen demasiado fáciles y aburridos. En juegos futuristas puedo hacer algunas excepciones porque es más coherente con la ambientación, pero en el caso de Mass Effect, aunque no lo considero negativo, tampoco me acaba de convencer. Los enemigos son más hábiles y peligrosos, equilibrando la dificultad, pero yo igualmente lo hubiera dejado como en el anterior juego.

- A parte de eso, lo que menos me gustó y que ya me chirriaba del primer Mass Effect, fue lo parco y simple que son las respuestas en las conversaciones. En juegos como Baldur's Gate y similares, puedes elegir con precisión lo que van a responder los personajes, pero en Mass Effect solo sale una palabra o frase corta. Al elegir la opción, el personaje responde con una frase más elaborada que no siempre coincide con lo que uno creía haber elegido.

- Tuve un problema con el movimiento del ratón que me obligó a buscar solución externa y finalmente pude resolver gracias a webs como "pcgamingwiki"

Un juego increíble, que creo que es justo valorar con la perspectiva de que se estrenó hace casi 13 años, y se hizo con la tecnología de hace 14 o 15. Por eso los pocos bugs, sobre todo con las hitboxes que te hacen retroceder un poco al atascarte en algún sitio, no las contaré.

La historia continúa donde la dejamos en Mass Effect 1, y los 3-4 años de diferencia entre un juego y otro se notan mucho. El mapa de la galaxia es una delicia y apetece explorar cada rincón, y el ritmo de las misiones es el adecuado, con una historia muy interesante. El combate, jugándolo en máxima dificultad (como casi siempre hago) es bastante aceptable para un juego de esa época, premiando la puntería solo en parte y haciendo que sea necesario hacer las misiones secundarias para mejorar el equipo, que se vuelve devastador con el paso del juego. Además, no resultan repetitivas y aportan un lore interesante.

El universo que creó Bioware en este juego es una pasada. Tenía pendiente este juego y la verdad es que tendría que haberlo jugado antes.

Gráficos: 7/10. Tengo que penalizarlo un poco porque es cierto que el diseño de niveles es quizá algo simple, pero teniendo en cuenta cuándo se hizo el juego está bastante bien.
Jugabilidad: 7,5/10. Es un poco tosca para estar en 2022, pero el combate está bien y 
Historia: 9,5/10 Una de las mejores historias que he jugado en un videojuego
Total: 8/10. Un gran juego, muy recomendable.

122253598.review:
Pretty decent sci-fi action RPG with a few issues. I don't think it's quite as breathtaking as everyone says it is, but I enjoyed my time with it very much.

Mass Effect 2 picks up with Commander Shepard et al. aboard their ship the Normandy, pretty soon after the end of the first game. In short order, they're lasered by a highly advanced flying piece of shit and everyone who isn't a named character dies. Shepard is scooped up by Cerberus, a morally dubious organisation with limitless resources and rebuilt as he was because they have the technology. With his new lease on life, he, and therefore you, must assemble a crack team of professional oversharers who understand even less about delegation than Shepard does, and take on the aliens who lasered you while investigating the disappearances of human colonies around the galaxy. And also do side quests with all the characters you assemble. So far, so good.

Mass Effect 2, moreso than 1, I think, is very good at developing at fleshing out the galaxy until it feels as epic as an actual galaxy. Every faction has different opinions, each subplot of each party member splinters off into their own missions that flesh out their perspective on the world. There's always a risk that "stop the destruction of the galaxy because dying is cringe" can become completely dull, but Mass Effect 2 understands there's no one single way to end up at that point. 

The running theme of the game that ties it all together is justice. Each character has their own reasons for allying with Shepard and therefore Cerberus, mostly related to their complete distrust in the beaurocracy of the Alliance to get things done mixed with a duty for good that might come from abuse, love, loyalty, etc.. But without guidance or different opinions, each falls victim to the flaws in their own notions of right and wrong. Does a "code" endorsed by generations of a species supercede laws? (No) Does murder become justified if the law is incapable of detaining someone peacefully? (Not really) Does a family member have the right to let themselves go to prison for their own reasons, even though the truth proves they shouldn't? (Not if the criminal gets to go free) You as Commander Shepard become the great mediator of the galaxy, standing in the middle of all these perspectives you gathered, respecting each for who they are even though their opinions differ, and making informed choices they never could have made otherwise. It's honestly all great stuff. 

I do have some gripes with how all this is presented, however. Of the eight total squad members, each mission allows you to choose two. The sheer number of missions combined with the number of combinations is an exponential volume of writing, that is reasonably not done. So oftentimes characters only have one or two dialogue lines acknowledging their situation. It missions with moral dilemmas to make, like side missions, the debates on the subject are freqently limited to the mission-specific party member and Shepard, plus some NPCs, and the third wheel party member stands in the background of each shot if they're shown at all. Other times missions have such absurdly evil villains that there's no need to debate anything. Fine for the overarching plot, I guess, not so much for side missions. The reason I'm bringing specific party members on these missions is for their specific worldviews and opinions on the matter, but when it just doesn't happen I feel very disappointed. This doesn't always happen, though. I remember a few lines in the mission for the last party member you meet that unexpectedly flipped my thinking on the moral dilemma of day while being completely in character. Moments like that stand out to as the best parts of the game.

Another problem with the limited dialogue is that there's not much room for showing without telling - understanding how this or that character thinks based on what they say about the events around them rather than being told how they think like you're reading a psych evaluation. Mass Effect 2 prefers the eval method when you talk to your squad between missions. And it can be ages before that conversation is paid off in a side mission. You walk in, get some info - very interesting info, mind you, the krogan in particular was fascinating -  then walk out. Occasionally there's a nice conclusion but I don't feel particularly resolved afterwards. It's annoying, but not a deal breaker by any means.

As for the gameplay, eh. It's functional. The guns have a nice kick to them. Getting party members to do things felt a bit unnecessary because by the time they've done their ability you could have just killed the enemy yourself. I played on normal and got away with only changing my ammo types and using the team revive ability. The movement can be a bit sluggish and it feels like there are magnets in the walls, but apart from that it's functional. It's a decent enough vehicle for the more interesting story, which is all you can ask for, really.

So, yeah, all in all, hearty recommendation. Good stuff.

115964035.review:
What can I really say that others haven't about this masterpiece of Sci-Fi.

You play as the amazingly recently revived Commander Shepard, on his quest to prevent aliens from kidnapping humans for their very evil plot. For this, you have to create a big crew of different races, professions and moralities. Together, led by Shepard, you will trek across systems of planets to discover clues and allies to help defeat the Collectors, [spoiler]who are puppets to the even great threat of the series antagonists, the Reapers.[/spoiler]

Overall this game is amazing, from the characters to the immersive worlds you get to play through, the game rarely lets you down aside from a few things here and there. The greatest aspect of the game however is the feeling of actually stepping into the boots of Shepard, and feeling like you're actually viewing all this from their perspective which makes you feel like you're actually becoming a space marine kicking Alien butt.

Game systems have been either removed or improved since the first game. For instance, the game now works on a more Gears of war-esk system of cover and ammo as apposed to the heat sink mechanic of the first one. The dialog system is roughly the same say for an increase in NPC's you speak with during the game, and can freely talk to whenever to ask questions. Speaking of dialog, more romance options were added to the game to further give players more choice. Characters now romanceable of note include Tali and Garus from the first game, two of the more popular team members that return for more action in this outing. Their romances honestly are some of the best in the game, where through these romances we learn some of their fears, desires and maybe a hint of longing that has been there since the beginning.

While I can sit here and speak for hours about how perfect this game is... There are some flaws that need to be spoken of. For instance, a lot of the early game feels slow and dull. [spoiler]Grunts mission being a huge bore from beginning to end.[/spoiler] This can be chalked up to that it's the first part of the game, and you need to wait to get into the real meat. Which only really starts at the 7-8 hour mark if you take your time and play through the game properly. Another flaw is that while the vast majority of the squad are amazing characters, some you will never pick and just kinda forget about. They also just feel like people that disappear and hide away on the ship till you seek them out to burnout their dialog tree until the next chapter in the game. Which contrasts to the first game, where there were times all the crew got their shine in the main story, where they had things to comment on and do during the main part rather than just their side stories that it felt organic.

Here? You meet them, get a cutscene, maybe romance them, get their loyalty mission, and maybe get a conflict cutscene where you need enough points to calm both sides down. And that's about it... I would of much preferred at least some members of the crew to comment on and help during mainline missions. .[spoiler]apart from Mordin, when his part is over her gets shunted away again...[/spoiler]. It unfortunately, also suffers from 7th gen brown screen, where most of this game looks like it had a can of Irn-Bru spilled all down it, which makes the game look really awkward and ugly in some places.

Overall, I love this game to death, I can live with its flaws and they don't stop me from playing the game from start to finish every time I pick it up. I can say honestly this is the best game ever made and I will die on that hill. If you want an epic romp across space to be a badass, then you found the right game for you.

113295242.review:
Tbh, I was dissappointed by the game. After playing ME1, a game from 2007, I expected the sequel to be at least as good, But unfortunately, apart from the improved graphics, the sequel brought a bunch of downgrades, the main ones being:
- limited RPG elements. The improvement points were seriously reduced, leaving only 3-4 stats per character to improve. Additionally the XP seems limited in comparison and each trait costs more for the higher lvl, which means you can level up, but can't improve any stat. Very unfulfilling and frustrating.
- repetitive missions. I played 16h and more than 20 missions and each looks identical to the prior one. You get to a zone with a linear map (can't explore, no open world, nothing) and there you basically have to shoot your way out. The shooting/killing missions are frustrating because of the limited ammo. I mostly used assault rifle and there were plenty of missions when I was running out of ammo for it and had to rely on my companions to finish the job. Just plain old frustrating.

Some good things included character special missions which unlock a special ability and a much larger squad. And the story which was interesting, same as in the 1st ME. But because the missions were so repetitive and the limited ammo BS made me lose interest quickly.

In what seems typical for Bethesda - a game with a lot of potential, but poorly executed.

Update:
- I played an additional 15h just to finish the game. The limited ammo thing was solved as I got an upgraded assault rifle that had more ammo and almost never ran out. But the missions still looked identical to the ones before. Shoot your way, duck for cover when injured. Rinse, repeat. No fun, except for the story.

Two years after ME1, Commander Shepard is back in action. This is a great sequel to an awesome first game. The view in the game is from the 3rd person camera, and we could argue that this is some kind of hybrid between pure shooter and a bit of an RPG.  

Once you assemble your team, you need to carefully communicate with your party members, you need to listen to them, check what problems they have, try to console them or help them solve some of their problems, and you will gain loyalty points, and they will be more eager to fight alongside with you and help you out.

The whole game is pretty interesting and well made, everything running smooth, the only problem with this game that I had is that is pretty linear. It is not an open world game in any way, and you must deal with missions in orderly fashion. There is no choosing, "oh, I can do that later". No, you can not buddy, you must do it now.

But beside that, this game is really good for something that was released in 2010. If you hadn't played it so far, go for it, you will not regret invested money in this game.

112342355.review:
So I was pretty impressed by ME1, specifically loved the story and a fun, half-casual gameplay. That said I couldn't help but notice that a non-casual challenge seeking approach wouldn't go well with it due to a number of small flaws (which mostly remain unnoticed in casual play). Anyway: I was excited to import my character to ME2 and continue a great journey!

As I interpret it Bioware noticed the same flaws I noticed and tried to fix them... and that's where things went wrong. 

Now we have ammunition, which leads to a need to change weapons in every fight and / or move a lot to collect clips during combat. To me (and a number of other people if I read the forum right) that feels forced and isn't really fun. I imagine it's supposed to break up a repetitive slow paced combat routine, which isn't necessarily a bad idea. XCOM2 tried the same with turn timers and it's basically the same problem: Forcing the player to play a style he never chose just doesn't feel right. Apart from that ME2 "fixed" the inventory clutter of ME1, but although it kinda works it also mostly gets rid of the fun of looting. 

The game now allows to start on Insane (highest difficulty) right away. That's a plus. Only these games are best enjoyed casually and the combat system doesn't necessarily scale up well with difficulty. Efficiency can lead to silly and non-fun gameplay. The focus on casual play is actually what makes most sense - it is and always has been bioware's biggest strength as I see it. The plot, characters and atmosphere make their games great and distracting from it just makes those games worse. Mind if You played KOTOR 1 & 2 or Dragon Age and saw it differently chance is You'll also see it differently here, since I perceive that as a generic bioware thing.

What I perceive as a major obstacle in designing a gameplay that works on very high difficulties without becoming silly might also be the clash of RPG and FPS. It's daring! Bioware RPGs seem to be real time, but under the hood their fantasy RPGs are more like continuous turn based games. That attracts certain players and a certain playstyle - different players and playstyles than First Person Shooters. Trying to allow both is tricky and I reckon that's a major part why it is really hard to come up with a solution that suits everybody. My guess, anyway. 
Perhaps going Vanguard class (close range and probably more action heavy) would be more satisfying for an FPS player. Since I lean towards tactical turn based RPGs I played Infiltrator (sniper) and was really annoyed to be forced out of cover, unable to carry enough ammunition to play through a single fight with my sniper rifle. Felt like my char is forced to do stupid. It's fine in difficulty, but it breaks with my idea of the character and diminishes exactly the very strength of bioware - storytelling. 

Plot wise it might be as good as ME1 I guess, but to me it doesn't feel like it yet. I'm not through yet, but I already lost my motivation. Although the story starts with the bang it basically [i]has to[/i] build up of course. After the high of ME1's endgame that didn't work too well for me: It feels shallow and can't seemlessly take off from where ME1 left us. It's not to be held against the game perhaps - it's just really hard to follow up on a great game. Sadly it feels, anyway. Add the gameplay disappointments and I'm kinda out of it. Heard similar perspectives from others on the forum.

Perhaps the biggest problem are the [i]high expectations[/i] I carried over from ME1. It's Mass Effect alright! Hence You might enjoy the game much more than I currently do if You temper Your expectations, perhaps take a break after ME1 before starting and meet the game with more of an open mind.

111497485.review:
Mass Effect 2 es polifacético.
Por un lado tiene cosas buenísimas y cosas que fueron para mejor y otras que son una absoluta mierda.
Por el lado bueno, el combate/gameplay mejoro una locura, es mucho mas frenético y con mejores animaciones.
La historia toma un rumbo muy bueno, con buenos diálogos y buena narrativa.

Por el lado malo...
Voy a empezar por las cosas que me parecían que estaban perfectas en el 1 y que acá se lo metieron en el forro del orto.
Las curaciones con medigel, DIOS LAS EXTRAÑO, para poder curarte tenias un recurso que te curaba a vos y a tu crew, te hacia estar al tanto de la vida tuya y de tus compañeros y lo mas importante, ME PODÍA CURAR CUANDO YO ELIJA!
Ahora hay un sistema de mierda de "espera detrás de una pared y a los 15 segundos, SI LE PINTA, voy a empezar a curarme solo"
ES HORRIBLE, no hace nada mas que entorpecer al juego y detenerme el ritmo de los enfrentamientos.
Los combates se resumen en:
1-Ir a cobertura.
2-Disparar hasta que mi vida baje a casi 0
3-ESPERAR COMO UN IMBECIL DETRAS DE COBERTURA HASTA TENER VIDA COMPLETA
4-Repetir.
Gracias a dios elegí una clase con una habilidad de salto y que recarga escudos porque sino seria UN EMBOLE.

El tema de hackeos y pirateo esta bien...las primeras 5 veces, después es super repetitivo e innecesario.
Una opción mejor seria una especie de skill llamada pirateo o hackeo y a medida que vaya subiéndola llegue un punto donde no tenga que estar un rato resolviendo el mismo puzzle de mierda que vengo resolviendo hace 45 horas de gameplay.
O no se, llevar a tali con la skill de hackeo alta y que por llevarla sea innecesario estar pirateando cada puta puerta.

La ausencia de granadas, se extrañan demasiado las granadas.

Los enemigos ahora son todos LAS MISMAS ESPONJAS DE DAÑO CON SKIN DIFERENTE, en el 1 había diferentes enemigos que cambiaban tu estilo de combate, recuerdo que se me fruncía el orto al ver un Krogan o un geth que saltaban, aquí ya son todos iguales, no cambian en nada.

Las misiones son aburridisimas, siempre es lo mismo, ve de punto A a B por medios de pasillos, mata enemigos en coberturas y al final de la mision todo se ramifica en 2 opciones:
*Un boss/mini boss con pelea minimamente interesante
*Resistir oleadas de enemigo porque -inserte excusa generica-
DIOS! SPAMMEROS DE MISIONES DE OLEADAS!
Nunca algo diferente, nunca un puzzle donde deba usar mis habilidades, nunca una mision donde mis compañeros tomen relevancia, nunca nada.
Siempre esas dos mismos tipos de misiones.
La unica mision interesante que recuerdo es del corredor sombrio, tiene un buen jefe final pero es solo un dlc, el resto de la historia siempre es lo mismo, pasillo simulator.
Con la cantidad de lore que hay entre las diferentes razas podían haberme puesto algún puto puzzle, algún acertijo o algo para avanzar en las misiones y hacerlos mas interesantes.
Desgraciadamente no fue el caso.

Realmente siento que el combate esta como relleno en esta saga de juegos, es muy malo e innecesario, realmente siento que armaron un esquema de "Historia - combate - Historia" y los combates solo están como excusa para tenerte un rato jugando a algo hasta terminar la misión y seguir avanzando en la historia.

Juegos como Uncharted de PS3 ya hacían un mejor sistema de misiones. Tenia puzzles que resolver, parkour, hambientes variados, desde la selva mas verde hasta desiertos bien marrones, misiones en aviones y auto.
Y todo lo mantenía con una buena historia, si, para nada compleja y enlazada como las de mass effect pero cumplía su lavor.

Si tan solo le dieran mucha mas relevancia al gameplay de combate este juego seria perfecto. Siento que no aprovechan bien lo que tienen y hacen un sistema de combate para cumplir.

Todo es igual, ve de punto A a B, entre medios de pasillos que cambian de skin según el planeta.
Mata a *esponja de daño con skin diferente*.
Enfréntate a boss o resiste oleadas.
Fin.

El único lugar miniamente memorable es el Afterlife, aquí puedo decir que hicieron una buena ambientación y es divertido pasarse por ahí, pero de ahí en mas no existe nada que sea recordable.

Sigo y mantendré mi opinión, HASTA ESTE JUEGO, mass effect seria mucho mejor juego si fuese un juego únicamente de narrativa con opciones.

No recomiendo esta versión, compraría la versión definitive edition y lo jugaría ahí.

108742402.review:
Mass Effect 2 is essentially a massive refinement of the ideas of 1. It does good on the promise of its power fantasy, and has much more thought put into its environment, characters and overall atmosphere. While I couldn't say it has a compelling main story, the characters and over-arching themes carry it along. Choices, while still pretty binary, are a lot more subtle and interweave far more complexly to create a much more rewarding experience. 

On the other hand however, the core gameplay, while improved still has some stutters. The cover system still feels almost too snappy, there's a lack of overall challenge, and I barely used any of my powers, opting for guns and guns and guns.

Still a really great game, aged particularly well, and remembered really fondly, rightfully so.

106838647.review:
Mass Effect 2, developed by BioWare and published by Electronic Arts, is a space opera RPG that stands as one of the most iconic and beloved games of its generation. Released in 2010, this installment in the Mass Effect trilogy transcends the boundaries of traditional storytelling and gameplay, offering players an unforgettable journey through the Milky Way galaxy. As a dedicated fan who has experienced Commander Shepard's epic quest multiple times, I'm thrilled to share my detailed review of Mass Effect 2.

Gameplay (10/10):
Mass Effect 2 refines the gameplay introduced in the first installment, creating an action-packed and immersive experience. The cover-based combat system is smooth and responsive, allowing for dynamic firefights against a variety of formidable foes. Character progression is more streamlined, with a wider range of powers and abilities that enable players to customize their Shepard's combat style. The loyalty missions for each squad member not only deepen their character development but also contribute to the game's overall strategy, as building a strong team is crucial to your success in the suicide mission at the game's climax.

Storytelling (10/10):
The narrative in Mass Effect 2 is a masterclass in storytelling. The stakes are higher, the mysteries are deeper, and the character-driven drama is both emotionally resonant and thought-provoking. The game excels in building a sense of urgency as Shepard assembles a diverse crew and confronts a new and insidious threat to the galaxy. Choices made in the first game carry over, shaping the world and relationships in meaningful ways, and new decisions further impact the fate of your crew and the galaxy. The game's ability to immerse players in its richly realized universe and its morally complex dilemmas is unparalleled.

Character Development (10/10):
Mass Effect 2 places a strong emphasis on character development, and it excels in this regard. Each squad member has a compelling backstory and loyalty mission that delves into their past, personal struggles, and motivations. The interactions with these characters, both in the heat of battle and during moments of quiet reflection aboard the Normandy, deepen your emotional investment in their fates. The choices you make throughout the game can lead to profound consequences, including the potential loss of beloved squad members, making every decision weighty and impactful.

Graphics and Sound (9/10):
In 2010, Mass Effect 2's graphics were a significant leap forward, with stunning character models and detailed environments. While they may not rival the visual fidelity of more recent games, the art direction remains captivating, and the cinematic presentation enhances the overall experience. The game's memorable soundtrack and expertly crafted sound design heighten the emotional impact of key moments and contribute to the immersive atmosphere of the Mass Effect universe.

Mass Effect 2 is often cited as a prime example of how narrative-driven games can excel. Its ability to weave complex storytelling, character development, and player choice into a cohesive and engaging experience has set a high standard for RPGs and narrative-driven games in general. The impact of the Mass Effect series on the industry as a whole, from storytelling to character development, cannot be overstated.

My personal journey with Mass Effect 2 has been one of profound emotional investment and awe. The characters, their struggles, and the decisions I made as Commander Shepard have left a lasting impact on me. Whether I'm replaying it to see different outcomes or revisiting the Normandy's crew, each playthrough continues to be a richly rewarding experience, and Mass Effect 2 remains a cherished part of my gaming history.

Mass Effect 2 is a space opera masterpiece that showcases the power of storytelling and character development in the gaming medium. Its immersive universe, morally complex choices, and memorable characters have solidified its status as a classic in the RPG genre. As a game that both challenges and resonates with players on a deep emotional level, Mass Effect 2 is a testament to the artistry of interactive storytelling and a must-play for anyone seeking an epic and unforgettable gaming experience.

////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Mass Effect 2 es un muy buen juego, en el que se han arreglado varias cosas de su antecesor en lo que es el sistema de armas, y la prospeccion de los planetas, aunque llegara un momento que iremos sobrado de material, pero en mi opinion no sobrepasa al primero. 102408614.review:
(this is a 5-part review; see the comments for the rest) There are a ton of improvements and changes this game made over its predecessor. AI is improved. So is the use of cover. Making the skill tree less complicated, more straightforward is easier, but there's still kind of a lot going on so it's hard to build a team and grow it and make each member capable of doing certain things (tank, glass cannon, sniper, mage, etc.). Each has their own strengths and weaknesses, true, but playing on those is difficult.

I miss all of the vehicular and extravehicular parts of the firs game. There's just straight-up no MAKO; rather than improve on it, they simply did away with it. I feel like that was an important exclusion, a missed opportunity. What did become easier was exploring all of the planets.

Resource acquisition is so crucial for the early game, but by somewhere around the midpoint it doesn't become so important because you have way more than enough resources to get the job done. Somewhere around 60% into this game I stopped picking every planet dry because I realized I would never go through my resource stockpiles. Most of the planets after that I just threw one probe onto it for the sake of completion progress. Later, I started going back on that just to see how many resources I could stockpile. I ended up with 60,000 eezo, and 200k-300k of everything else.

The difficulty in acquiring money was challenging to work through. I had thought it to be unbalanced and unfair, but it's actually a very crucial check on advancing in the game. It's almost impossible to get *all* of the upgrades in one playthrough, but it's very telling that you can get *almost* all of them in one playthrough if you're careful. I ended my game with just 20,000 credits and only 1-3 outstanding upgrades left (all on the citadel).

The level design was deeply inspired. Gone are the repetitive building interiors of part 1, where a lot of the mercenary/pirate/cerberus buildings were carbon copies of each other. Every single structure you fight in and around is unique. This is seriously inspired level design. No two scenarios play alike. I think there's something like fifty different levels in this game? Maybe more? All were individually designed to be unique and serve a purpose, and the gameplay revolves around that. There is some literal, genius-level architecture involved here. Scenario design, too. The weakness of the actual scenario design is that it felt somewhat repetitive: you could always expect some amount of a given resource, unlocking computers for bonus money, etc. in every level. It was just repetitive enough to feel like it was breaking the immersion, and yet even THAT was covered up just enough by the amazing level design to make me not care all that much about it. Had the level design not been as good, the repetition would have been more ingratiating. Part of the repetition was getting resources that I already had piles of, and so the acquisition felt unnecessary.

One part that really bugged me was how few people you actually got to rescue when you discovered unknown or undiscovered ship crashes, boardings, etc. ALL of the "good" people were killed or slauthered or disappeared. Almost no one was left to rescue. It was sad. I carried that with me through the game. "Parting is such sweet sorrow" indeed.

The character DAS (design, acting, scripts) were deeply inspired. Easily as good if not better than the first game. That doesn't necessarily mean the character DAS wasn't good in the first game - it was at least as good as any big-budget Hollywood film - but it's that somehow they found a way to make it ALL even better in this game. What an unbelievable feat. This was due in no small part to all of the veteran voice acting talent. The ONLY two sticking points to me: 1) Shepard's dialogue, at times, felt somewhat terse and forced. It wasn't just the voice acting - and I definitely had an issue with the voice acting - but it was also the facial expressions and mannerisms. Shepard was supposed to be the rock, the one everyone could depend on. Not once did he shed a tear for anyone. The other sticking point was that Keith David's character really just didn't do much. There was almost almost zero interaction with the council, but I'll go over that in the next paragraph.

The council and political discussion is below. For now, I want to give major props to the amazing voice talent in this game:

Joker - Seth Green (Idle Hands, Robot Chicken, Family Guy)
Jacob - Adam Lazarre-White
Shepard - Mark Meer, Jennifer Hale (Metal Gear Solid series as Naomi Hunter, and many more)
Garrus Vakarian - Brandon Keener. I REALLY liked the character of Garrus, and I feel like he only got better in the second game. They gave him a ton of emotional depth and growth as a character, and it was very refreshing to see.
Tali'Zorah - Ash Sroka. Tali being considered a romance option took me completely by surprise. Her also having an extremely involving and challenging character arc was also a surprise. The exceptional job they did developing her character, and the amazing voice acting and scenario design around her character, was definitely a welcome change. I definitely missed having Ash as a romantic partner, but I guess the inner Captian Kirk in me won out because I definitely fell in love with a purple-skinned alien babe.
Liara T'Soni - Ali Hills. Liara played a more minor role, and yet it was still a pleasure to see her. Ali did an amazing job voicing her again. I can tell she thoroughly enjoyed getting lost in the moment portraying Liara.
Mordin - Courtenay Taylor. Holy hell, Mordin doing theatre & singing was unexpected! It was goofy and spontaneous! And good! This is the kind of exceptional character design and thought that went into this game, and why I continued to enjoy playing it.
Grunt - Steve Blum (Cowboy Bebop as Spike Spiegel). Grunt is an amazing character. It helps that he's the best tank in the game, but despite being the Mass Effect analog of a caveman or gorilla or a Klingon, he's a surprisingly deep and complicated character. Steve Blum's acting absolutely helped Grunt come to life as a completely unique character in the game.
Thane Krios - Keythe Farley. I lost Thane in my playthrough, and definitely felt sad to be without him. He was a complicated character. His was a story of suffering and redemption. If you want a close example of what Thane is like, read "The Way of Kings" Book 1 of the Stormlight Archive. Thane is almost equal to Szeth in that book.
Samara - Maggie Baird. I really loved this deep, insightful character. I have to wonder how difficult it was to properly voice Samara given that she was supposed to be warm and caring, yet cold and calculating like a machine. There's a lot of emotional complication going on there.

Now, on to the politics: (see comments)

100206013.review:
They removed the RPG and loot elements from the first game and made a generic cover based shooter. I played through it twice to try a combat focused character rather than my original sentinel from ME1 and it was still pretty bad. Enemies just spawn in from around corners in areas out of reach like it's an arcade shooter. The paragon vs renegade is no longer a morality counter but two separate bars you just fill up so that you can choose to punch someone in a weird sort of mid-dialogue QTE. Rather than tactically managing combat you just shoot things, and rapidly regenerate health after a few seconds of not being shot yourself. And whenever you talk to the leader of a terrorist organisation who tried to kill you in the last game you only seem to have the options of agree or strongly agree.

I guess that if you just want a sci-fi shooter then you could like this one. But after playing the first game I wanted more RPG less shooter. This was very disappointing to me.

One small positive is that Wrex is in the game. He doesn't join you, but it's nice to talk to see him again.

100181211.review: Loved open world aspect throughout the Milky Way galaxy. Also, each character is written with detail and come to life in this game.

99883055.review:
ME2 pretty much improves on almost everything from ME1. 
The writing is way above the writing of ME1, the voice acting and animation range, expressions on characters, more dynamic camerawork, scenes moving more, combat better realized, a story that builds in a great way on top of ME1, even small optional assignments that have more varied locations and different gameplay aspects to them, it's all great.

But there are some worrying parts to ME2, the EAification is already visible.
The insane amount of DLC, from the typical horsearmor stuff, new weapons and armor with better stats, to squadmates and their loyalty missions, to big story quests that are a bit important to tying events together. Most of those are actually good.
And I can sympathize with devs being between a rock and a hard place. As you don't want DLC to just be pointless filler, that too will feel like ripping off players, you want DLC to feel like it's worth the money, something that was made with care, effort, passion. But, it's also something that, because it can be great and feel right at home in a game, could feel sleazy to a player being this thing not already integrated into the base experience without forking over more cash.

The sad truth is that ME2 on its own on Steam is an incomplete experience, you're missing out on great stuff without all the expansions that are available on Origin.
But where there's a will there's a way, one that doesn't involve anything illegal or fishy.
There's a Steam Guide going over steps to play ME2 on Steam legitimately with all the DLC. The catch is that you have to own ME2 & the DLC on Origin. But, if you have them there already, or will buy it on sale, then the steps are to make sure CD keys from Steam are registered on your Origin version, make sure you've logged into the Cerberus account (EA online) in ME2 on origin (you can uninstall it from origin after that and don't need to open Origin again), then install ME2 on Steam and make sure to also log in your Steam version ME2 with the same EA login, download all DLC manually to install for the Steam version, login again to your steam version of ME2 with EA online, and it should work, you don't need to login anymore.
After that install mods from nexusmods with the ME3tweaks modmanager if you so desire, Project Variety could be good, but I've also had some issues, bugs, crashes with it.

To most that will understandably be too much, I have enough love for Mass Effect and enough intolerance to EA Origin these days that this wasn't an issue, and I've had a smooth fun complete experience of ME2 on steam now.

Story picks up shortly after ME1, takes some neat twists and turns. And though there's a slightly grittier tone to ME2, it's also a lot more humorous, fun, bombastic, and has more environmental jokes sprinkled in with just overall more personality and charm than before. 
A lot more action integrated into your roleplaying and not just gameplay and dialogue. 
I remember not particularly liking the "interrupt" system originally, it felt too QTE-like to me, but on replaying, I see a place for them, it's not like failing to press in time the paragon/renegade interrupt will result in an instant death like is normal in videogame QTEs, but it's a choice, even not taking the opportunity is a part of that roleplaying (though usually taking them is more fun when you can). Interrupts allow a scene to flow without having to pause with characters just statically standing there locked in a conversation, but create a choice that's not necessarily just words or shooting, but an action.
Also appreciated in ME2 is how Paragon isn't necessarily anymore just a complete pacifist and diplomat, but can have an edge to them. And the romance feels slightly less forced, turning someone away can still feel like you're being friendly and on the same page.

I've always liked the connection between the games, transferring a save, having that character, with their history with the previous characters, even if very limited and shown in offhand incidental dialogue, it's still enough to give a sense of having spent time with them, having built a companionship through adventures you've shared throughout.
I wish ME2 had what ME3 had, with characters not just standing in their designated rooms just waiting quietly for Shepard to approach and talk with them, that's a positive ME3 did where you could find them between missions in different areas, possibly talking with different people.

The Animation quality is greatly improved over ME1. 
Many NPCs, critical and even incidental ones, have more varied and unique animations, so that you see less often the same ones, smiles, crying, angry expressions not only look better but are used more often to lessen the feeling that you're talking to robots, only Shepard comes off more robotic when you see them more often just asking a neutral question, and the transitions between animation states is smoother, which was a bit jarring in ME1. And the camerawork, more frequently dynamic framing of a scene coupled with more expressively distinct gestures makes each shot more lively, polished. Not to mention the improved writing, more characters that feel distinct from each other with different styles of speaking, both in voice acting and words. You put those together, more varied animations, better individualized engaging writing with voice acting, smoother more dynamic camerawork, and a lot more scenes now stick out and feel really satisfying to watch and engage in.

There are a lot of cute little optional "missions" that the game doesn't really throw in your face, just scan a planet, and run into one, and there's a lot less recycled content in them, the areas don't repeat like they did in ME1, and they can even be noncombat areas, just switching it up. Which was refreshing, as a person who tends to have that 100% completionist urge, it felt good to just go around the galaxy and see if I could find more of those missions that will switch things up between planet scanning (which can get repetitive) and bigger missions.

Combat follows more of of the action shooter variety than a traditional RPG, you pick up new weapons that serve different roles, like you're playing a FPS with a swiss army knife arsenal, powers too, enemies have weapon variety and shields/barriers/armor that sticks out more and creates more of a need to prioritize and match your tools to their makeup. It's still fun, a bit frustrating at times though, there can be that bullet sponginess to enemies which require you to optimize how you hit them.
Squad AI does seem surprisingly stupid, they do very little on their own, shotgun squadmates run away to sniper ranges, they stay behind cover with poor line of sights, you feel forced to keep giving them specific orders a lot.
Also a subjective thing, I did not like the original controls, having spacebar do interact/sprint/cover/mantle, so I edited my coalesced ini separating them, exclusive use for E, Shift for sprint, spacebar could be mantle and cover/exit, then I made middle mouse button to command both squadmates to move/attack combined, just so that I could more easily stay in the action without awkwardly individually in the moment give commands. Made the experience a lot smoother and juicier.
Just something you can do if you want more control over bindings.

To save space I'm going to skip my usual performance points, just say that it runs well enough on a 7 year old potato laptop, and that ME2 is one of the greats, a fun followup to ME1 and the continuation of both story and your own journey, even if with a bit of illusory decisionmaking, still is a good enough magic trick to create that sense of it being your personal story with characters you've bonded with, appealing to universal human nature.
Steam version needs a lot of effort for the best experience, but hey, Steam DRM gives a much better service than Origin.

98278192.review:
I have been playing games for 25 years. There has been cases where I found the critically acclaimed game to be just OK (Bioshock Infinite) and critically okayed game to be brilliant (Darksiders), but I've never had a case where I found the critically praised and universally beloved game to be absolute trash until Mass Effect 1&2.

I just don't get what's in this game that people love. I can name 20 games released before this that looks, feels and plays a 100 times better than this. 

- The graphics is garbage. The characters look like malformed wax models. The environment looks like prototypes created by amateurs
- The gunplay sucks, the mouse sensitivity is too high, I never feel I am in control. And I hate those pew pew guns. It's so easy to duck and dodge. Just give me an AK47
- And those $hitty cover mechanics. Shepard's head is always sticking out but no one can shoot him when he is covering. But when the enemy is ducking and covering, I can shoot his head. That is just lame.
- Another thing I hate about cover mechanics in general. When there is a cover crate then I know the enemies are going to come in soon. It simply spoils the surprise. And the enemies are so stupid. They keep shooting when I am in cover knowing fully well that the shots wont hit me.
- Movement is trash. Guy can't run fast enough and just a little bit of exertion and he gets tired. WTF
- Lighting is all fu*ked up. The shadows are all at the wrong places. And there is no shades, it just goes black. We are supposed to be in 22nd century in all the glory of the future and the rooms are not well lit?? I mean who the f designed the lighting??
- facial mechanics is laughable. Eyes has it's own mind, mouth has it's own mind. And it's interplay is laughably ugly. I can't make those faces even if i try.
- Oh and those dialog choices. It is so frustrating to see one thing on the screen and Shepard uttering something else. This was touted as an innovation but it's a passing fancy at best and irritating crap at worst.

ok given, story is mildly interesting and dialog mechanics are competent. 

So all in all, headache inducing movement, levels built with cardboards, graphics engine created by amateurs... and 94 on metacritic???

10/100

97981669.review:
Feels like Star Trek!

Its my first playtrought. I am almost at the end. 

A classic Sci-Fi experience. It "feels like Star Trek!" The story is quite light but interesting. Characters arcs aren't to deep but also quite well put together. There is alot of interesting dialogue to be had with choices (Sometimes you need to make 'em quick!) that impact the game world and ending of course. Not to be mistaken with the dialogue choices  to be found in older action rpg's like FNV, fallout 3 and Oblivion and so on but more in like with Horizon: Zero Dawn. It gives the game a movie-like feeling and the story progresses in a healthy pace because of this imo. 

I am a 50% fan of this combat system because it feels clunky. Sprinting and cover fail so much. And thats about it but it has a big impact on the overall combat. Gun variety is not there but I actually like that. It is just more fun to not have to get distracted with gear. It is not so much a part of the game. Basically you get  four/five types of weapons as you progress trough the game and you can upgrade the overall damage output of the class of weapons via upgrade tokens/resources. Thats it. The biotic powers are fun. Not over the top just some basic stuff. They kept it simple. Again a fine choice imo. 

The Quests are okay. Some are fun. Some are interesting. Some are intruiging and some are sad. But they failed to deliver a quest that combines all of these. Not one quests touches me emotionally so deep that it makes it interesting to think about afterwards. I feel RPG's miss out on this alot lately and also back in the day. Make it a grind. Keep 'em busy. Mass effect isn't that bad as that of course. I would rate the quests 7/10 actually. They have a really fun and exploring vibe to them. Like I said - Star trek. Only SOME side-quests are really meh. Very boring and some they even forced in the game. With dialogue and animations that are just cringe. 

All round this is a very solid  RPG with mistakes in clunky combat. Some bad scripting in side-quests and the occasional bug here and there. (Quite often). But I would recommend this game instantly to an avid Sci-fi fan!

97815647.review:
You should be aware of this:
- This game REQUIRES an EA On Line account to validate a key (provided by Steam on startup).
- There is NO native controller support.  You have to use a mod to play with one.
- Ultra wide 3440x1440 resolution support is not working properly (the one from the launcher, not found in game).  I used Flawless Widescreen to correct that.
- If you wanna romance Liara you'll have to pay for the DLC

Putting away my hate for EA, I have to admit this is a great game.  I did't like that much ME1, to many flaws to my taste... But ME2 corrected everything I can complain of.  That clumsy tank was removed and there is no more boring repetitive exploration.  ME2 also improved the gunplay and the micromanage of ammo.  Secondary missions are tolerable now, even fun sometimes.  Loyalty missions are great for the most part.

95530224.review:
The only reason this game gets a thumbs up from me is because I'm not big on RPGs, and I feel there's something I've missed in this game, something that drives so many fans crazy about this franchise. Plus, there are a few moments that carry this game for me.

That being said, Mass Effect 2 has to be one of the least enjoyable experiences I've ever had in gaming. This game is an RPG, and that RPG-ness makes itself known through gameplay (weapons, powers, 'builds') and the choices you make throughout the story.

The gameplay is bad. It's absolutely pathetic. Even by 2010 standards, this gameplay and mission design is bonafide Prothean era. Your weapons and your powers (should you choose to have them) make themselves available in the most clunky way imaginable. Your squadmates' AI is laughably bad at best, and cancer at worst. It's not just that the gameplay is bad, it's that the levels feel endless, with the same bad corner-based shooter loop lasting for far longer than it should. It genuinely feels like BioWare thought they have the best damn gameplay in the world and decided to put the player through the same rut again and again. The game will drop you on an alien planet and force you to explore it with pathetic exploration mechanics that will make you long for some action. When you do get to the action, you'll want nothing more than to leave the fight sequences behind. The gameplay also wrecks any sort of 'immersion' you're expecting in this game. 

The story side of things is where I'm a bit conflicted. For the most part, I didn't like it. Except for 3 levels, one of them being the final level (you know the one), every single 'RPG' aspect of this game feels more like spur-of-the-moment rather than something you earned. This game doesn't even have a lot of 'main story' missions, mostly just recruitment and loyalty missions that don't advance the overall plot too much. They add a lot to the lore, sure but that sort of gets old after a while. Of course, what little storytelling most missions do have is marred by bad gunplay. 

I've heard a lot about people playing this game, again and again, to see the different choices and the different outcomes. Unfortunately, I did not see any merit in warranting another playthrough. 

My recommendation is to get the Legendary Edition and play ME1- import save to ME2 - play ME - import save to ME3 - play ME3 - eventually be greeted by an ending that doesn't care about your choices at all. DO NOT make the same mistake I did, which is playing this game as a standalone experience.

As someone who did play this game as a standalone experience, it's pretty damn clear to me how this is the same BioWare that ended up making Anthem. With what little I've seen, I do not doubt that these guys can make a decent RPG game. But an Action/Adventure game? Pfft.

95057984.review: Mass Effect 2 is a fantastic sequel to the already amazing first game. The story picks up exactly where Mass Effect finishes, only to immediately jump two years in the future to find an excuse why Commander Shepard’s powers and abilities have changed. Some controls and gameplay mechanics have changed too, most for the better, some for worse. Equipment management is much simpler, and the tedious exploration missions are gone. Unfortunately, all important actions are mapped to one button, which sometimes makes life harder and not easier. Much has improved though, from the third person shooting to the exploration of the galaxy as a whole. The story has a rough start, but soon picks up the pace and delivers a very rich experience, with three dimensional characters that each have understandable motives and relatable stories. This somehow makes the main storyline feel less central to the game this time, which feels a bit odd, but thanks to some amazing DLCs and an incredible finale, it makes up for it in the end. With a stellar cast, good graphics and a satisfying cliff-hanger ending, this game is certainly one of the best space operas out there.

Una vez finalicé Mass Effect 1 habiendo lo disfrutado al máximo, quise probar el Mass Effect 2, dicen que las segundas partes no son buenas, pero... esto no se aplica a este título, si el Mass Effect 1 te gusto, el 2 te va a encantar.

 Seguimos la historia un tiempo después de lo que paso en el primer Mass Effect, pudiendo importar tu partida del primer juego lo cual te da ciertos beneficios, la historia realmente esta genial y hay muchísimas misiones secundarias practicamente diferentes todas ellas y valen la pena hacerlas no solo por las recompensas, si no por que expande el mundo del juego contándote diferentes historias,  etc.

After enjoying the first game, I was curious to see how the story progressed, since continuing characters across games is still somewhat of a rarity.
By and large, it's still as good as the first game in many ways, except one of the most critical, in my opinion. They functionally don't let you play a character of your design. Even with Paragon/Renegade points left over from ME1, I was locked out of things because i wasn't Renegade/Paragon enough, even though the options I would have picked would have given me points in a given path, and are exactly what the character would have said. 
This hit a "nope, I'm out" threshold with a quest that I could not complete without more points, and no way to get them (that made sense in character), combined with a quest that I functionally "completed" (by denying help),  that the game wanted to *force* me to help (and pick a side).
This anti-RPG mechanic killed my interest in the story and franchise, full stop. It stopped being my character's story and became a story they wanted to tell.
