93326806.review:
[h1] Almost Ideal ? [/h1] 
  Mass Effect 2 - the second part of a wonderful trilogy from BioWare. Winner of multiple awards (including GOTY 2010) and probably one of the best sci-fi game out there. So, what is this game about ? 
  Let's start with a story - just like in ME 1, - it is amazing. It is a story of love, friendship, family. Story about overcoming difficulties for the sake of a higher goal. The only possible downside is that for the first ≈ 10 hours of gameplay almost nothing happens in terms of story. In the middle of the game, story slowly but surely developing and "accelerating". And in the final - the story "explodes" and hits you hard. Throughout the game, player can experience all possible kinds of emotions. Story is deep, emotional and dramatic. It is simply necessary to experience and go through it to understand how great and "powerful" it really is. 
   Compared with ME 1, gameplay has changed a little. Now, feels like it become less RPG-type and more shooter-type game. A couple of new interesting mechanics and things were implemented. Sadly, secondary missions became even more uninteresting and monotone: Travel to another planet → Kill everyone → Mission completed. Of course, there are exceptions, but this is the majority of secondary missions. Other than that, gameplay is great. Brilliant and unique combat system. Excellent dialogue system - you can literally spend hours talking to other characters. Overall, character development is insane. Each character is unique and feels alive. It is not just a bunch of emotionless dolls.  Also, game has interesting weapon/equipment/character upgrade system. Lots of different skills, mechanics. And although I must admit that sometimes it might feel like the game is boring - especially when doing secondary missions, it happens extremely rare - thanks to the interesting and unique gameplay.
   Talking about the graphics, ME 1 looked absolutely incredible for it's age (2007). In ME 2, obviously there are some improvements, but really nothing special. For 2010 game looks just fine. Also, throughout all the  ≈ 35 hours of gameplay, I haven't "discovered" any bugs, glitches or crashes. 
  [b]  Mass Effect 2 is a great game. It has incredible story, interesting and unique gameplay and also an ok graphics with great technical part. Mass Effect 2 is a one unforgettable journey. Therefore, I would recommend this game to everyone. If you somehow missed it, don't waste anymore time and play this. Definitely worth your time.   [u] 9/10 [/u] [/b]

92880789.review:
Overall a fun game, with a few caveats to that statement.

This game is a lot more action based than the first game, and it had a lot of cool moments to it, along with solid choices that effected the individual stories and plot-lines. I only played this recently, so the game probably felt much different in January 2010, but I still feel like the game aged pretty well and it's still got charm/value to it. Shooting felt fun thanks to the inclusion of special abilities, ammo augmentation with skills, and the ability to freely control where your allies take cover mid combat, though there was probably a little too much combat, wherein I was more excited for the dialogue choices and narrative.

Building the crew was satisfying, with an assortment of very interesting personalities in it (Tali waifu asf). Overall the quests to earn their membership to your crew and the loyalty missions were pretty fun and their own little quirky adventures.

Now tot he caveats: 

1) No cloud save means that if you beat 1 and then get a new computer without manually transferring the save files, means you lose access to all the work (I) you put into (my) your first game's paragon run that did almost all of the side content. There are apparently save files you can find online, I didn't do that and didn't think to do that till 10 hours into this one, overall just kind of shitty though. Especially since the default state is literally a trash run of mass effect 1, ie you have bad choices from the first game, did no side content at all, etc. This is extra bad because you are honestly probably locked out of choices in this game too, I due to doing loyalty missions in another order than the meta, had EVERYONE but Miranda's loyalty, which I think might play a part in the save file going forward. I also had to make a decision I didn't really want to make to get paragon points to try to alter that fate, but it didn't work. 

2) Scanning planets to probe for resources/misc side missions is pretty god damn monotonous and boring, holy crap, what a waste of time the actual probing for resources is, even if it's needed to a point to get an optimal ending + do misc side quests on the planets that aren't tied to your crew.

3) Without looking online, you don't know where the point of no return to do side content is, luckily I knew.

4) I don't like the inclusion of ammo, the first games charging guns that had cool-downs after overheating them was perfect for the setting and everything, this just added another annoying small thing.


Overall a good game worth playing (if you play 1 first, both for technical reasons and narrative reasons), but with some annoying aspects to it, but still pretty great, EA and BioWare don't make games like this anymore.

92412090.review:
TLDR:  Excellent blend of action and role-playing.

Mass Effect 2 is an perfect example of a game that builds on its predecessor and takes the next step.

ME2 opens shortly after the events of the first game. If the player completed ME1 and has a save file, they will be given the option of importing that file with their already-built character and with the choices/consequences at the end of that previous game (though they appear somewhat minimal). Shepard and the Normandy are attacked by an unknown foe, the good commander is blown into space ... and the game begins.

In general, ME2 functions much like the first game; the player has an overarching mission (quest) to achieve and a lot of running around to do in the meantime. You get messages about potential team members you'll need to stop the Big Bads, and have to set off to recruit them from various far-flung locations around the galaxy. Some of them will be familiar from the first game and it was always fun to be reunited with my old teammates. The ship interface, to fly around the galaxy--where you can probe planets for minerals needed to upgrade gear and find side-missions--is pretty simple and easy to use. You'll engage in dialogue with a multitude of characters, which gives you the option to make create "good" engagements (paragon) or "bad" (renegade). The former generally involves acting more just, even-handed, and selfless, while the latter is more cocky or aggressive. The further a character gets down the paragon or renegade scale, the more dialogue options in those trees open up. Some of these decisions come up as color-coded Quick-Time-style events in dialogue, so be ready with a quick left/right mouse-click during cut scenes.

Each of your potential followers is involved in some kind of local trouble you'll have to resolve before they can join your team. These missions also frequently offer other rewards in the course of solving them, such as equipment upgrades and credit opportunities. After each team member has been with you for a little bit, options to perform an additional (usually harder) quest for each of them comes available. Completeing those quests will earn their "loyalty" which unlocks additional powers. The recruitment and loyalty missions are the core of the game, and to me, were the most enjoyable aspects of ME2. The increase in loyalty also becomes very important for resolving the final mission. (Note: some loyalty missions can be failed, so judicious uses of saves is encouraged.) There are some missions unrelated to team members and/or the main story-line but they are incidental and unless you are a completionist or are looking for specific upgrades, are not necessary to finish the game. But I recommend doing every recruitment and loyalty mission, because those results matter.

And so do choices. The final mission to stop the enemy is all but a suicide run, after terrible things have happened in-game. It is entirely possible for the player to get through said mission with all their members--or lose them all. Or even themselves. All of that is based not only on the decisions the player makes in the moment but on the choices made throughout the game. There are walkthroughs for perfect runs but I heartily recommend during your first playthrough, just making the choices you want and letting the chips fall where they may. I found that much more fun, and even though I did lose a single teammate on the final mission (which was depressing) it gave the game a more visceral feel.

That said, the final mission was surprisingly easy. Making decisions about which teammate to send where were harder than the fighting.

The combat in general was pretty smooth and easy. I am glad they dismissed the "overheating weapon" concept from the first game and just went with "replaceable thermal clips" for weapons this time (basically, hit R for reload). In addition to the pistol-shotgun-assault rifle-sniper rifle combo, there is a "heavy weapons" category, with several weapons of various effects, including grenade and missile launchers, and particle beams. ME2 also dispensed with that questionable ATV combat mode from the first game--or, if they didn't, I never ran into it in game.

The environments are attractive, colorful, and varied, from vibrant cities and space stations, to rusted out hulks of derelict ships and planets covered in debris. All of the dialogue is fully-voice-acted and the quality is excellent. In general, I thought the graphics were good but facial-movement rendering was an issue, unfortunately, and Shepherd's plastic lips always looked off. The game felt quite stable; I never experienced a crash or any stutters. I regrettably did not try any of the DLC.

All in all, Mass Effect 2, is a great game that I think a lot of RPG fans will like. Choice matters here, but the real choice it to grab this game and enjoy it.

Pros
- Good action, smooth combat
- Meaningful RPG choices
- Wide galaxy to explore

Cons
- Final battle was a bit underwhelming
- Facial animations a little off

Final Score: 8/10

I had no expectation coming into Mass Effect 2 but I got so involved in that world. The sci-fi universe they built is so cool. 92145871.review:
Anybody who isn't a newbie to the Mass Effect series has already played this game, so, newbies, listen up: this game is a [b] MASTERPIECE[/b].

 I've never played the other games in the Mass Effect trilogy (though I will now) and had very little knowledge about the overarching plot between them before playing this game. Even still, this game enthralled me within the first twenty minutes. Sure, there were times when I was a little confused about who characters were or what they were talking about, but I ultimately think this game is very accessible for new players, especially with the Genesis DLC (don't forget to download all the DLC [url=https://help.ea.com/en/help/faq/dlc-for-classic-games/] here[/url]). Please don't be scared off if you're unfamiliar with the series because you will be missing out on one of the best games ever made.

One of this game's biggest strengths is how it approaches non-linear storytelling (the "your choices shape the narrative" system). In fact, it does this better than most modern games. Big and small, there are so many choices to make here. Some may have profound impacts on the story while others may only affect how smoothly interactions go, but they all feel like they matter. For example, even if you've been building a relationship with/romancing a character throughout the entire game, one bad decision can set you back to negative first base with them (and you won't unlock their special power). You can make some REALLY fucking terrible calls and [i] REALLY [/i] fuck things up, which adds so much replay value to the game.

While I could go on for days about the things this game does right, there are some things it doesn't do so well. Firstly, while the shooting mechanics have aged pretty well, the cover system makes me want to bash my head in with a fucking rock. It's one of those "snap-to-cover" systems that's really clunky and has just enough input lag when snapping in and out of cover to be really frustrating to deal with. On top of that, interact, sprint, and enter/exit cover are all permanently bound to the same key, so you're probably going to be striking up conversations and getting into cover more than you'd like. Shepard also has this bad habit of getting stuck inside objects, so I recommend following [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Mass_Effect_2#Clipping_into_walls.2Fobjects] this guide [/url] to fix it. While you're at it, just go ahead and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/24980/discussions/0/1700541698682921708/] remove the unnecessary 62 fps cap [/url] as well :).

The devs clearly put so much love into this game, which just makes me wish the BioWare of old was still making games.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] People call this one of the best games ever made for a reason.

The greatest instalment, in the greatest sci-fi trilogy of all time. Bar none. This game has a much darker, and more desperate tone than the original and it is all the better for this change. Renegade Shepard shines, even Paragons get their hands dirty at times. The gameplay is a combination of action shooter, blended with classic RPG elements to make a wonderful blend of depth without complicating things. The combat is revamped from the original and serves as the foundation of which Mass Effect 3 will base its combat on. The great voice acting from the original continues to shine here, especially from Martin Sheen's performance as the Illusive Man; simply iconic.

While the Legendary Edition is the one to get (it supports 21:9, while this original iteration does not), there is nothing wrong with experiencing Mass Effect 2 in its full, authentic glory. After all, this is peak BioWare!

90883718.review:
Moving on from Mass Effect this was a step up in gameplay and story. The levels are still rather linear in nature which allows the story to move in a coherent manner. The start of the game drew me in and the missions in the game based around your companions are very varied and involving. By the time I got to the end mission of the game I was starting to really trust my companions and couldn't stop playing. It was engrossing, captivating... like being part of a movie.

Which I gather is the point. I could go into detail about game mechanics and how combat has improved since Mass Effect, the seemingly pointless mining of planets for resources which it appears I really didn't need by the end of the game, the gratuitously (un)necessary cinematic camera angles during certain dialogue etc. but let's face it. These are a means to an end which is to bring the player into an epic story that spans over three games. That my actions and decisions in Mass Effect carried on into Mass Effect 2 is something I've not seen done in a game before. It's brilliant. It means the Mass Effect universe is one that I influenced. It feels more real.

Yet this goal has a downside: I don't want to replay the game. This isn't a criticism of the game. It's because my choices were ones I made, sometimes on the spur of the moment. Just like in real life, sometimes you regret those choices, but you have to live with them. To replay the game would take away those consequences. You don't need to have a perfect playthrough to enjoy the game. If anything any imperfection just increases the satisfaction level if you make it through.

If you've never played Mass Effect, you're missing out. This is the best blend of game and cinema I've experienced.

Even more polished than Mass Effect 1, the world/story/characters are just as well written and executed. The combat is slightly revamped, a bit faster paced and more focused on cover and ability usage compared to ME1. The loot has been streamlined as well, moving away from collecting hundreds of variants of the same items. Vehicle exploration has been removed in favor of a tedious scanning mode, it's frankly awful.

Overall though, a really solid sequel to ME1 - seamless integration of story with choices made in the first game having effects in the world of the second. Graphics look a bit better, combat is smoother, plenty of fun missions and a huge focus on replayability with your choices having major effects on the story and characters.

88028524.review:
A narrative masterpiece that fundamentally improves and evolves ME1 into one of the greatest RPG experiences.

Note: DLCs must be downloaded externally. Search "EA dlc for classic games" and you can find installers for them there. I recommend the complete package before beginning. DO NOT PLAY WITHOUT THE DLCs, SERIOUSLY.

Improving on the lore and foundations of ME1, ME2 introduces an even wider array of unique characters, and a galaxy of people you actually care about. Where ME1 failed in its gameplay, ME2 succeeds. While movement is still sluggish, the level design works alongside this, with reduced walking simulator, and much better curated segments. No more open world nonsense, just curated levels. Combat feels much better, though still somewhat shallow, but is more than passable. Side content, just like the main content, now feels much better, and I thoroughly enjoyed all of it.

The crew really make ME2 special. Meeting returning characters from ME1, mourning any potential losses, discussing how lives have changed, revelling in victories, or meeting new friends and new enemies - uncovering a dark future never felt so good when fighting alongside these characters. I have never [i]cared[/i] as much as I have for a bunch of characters as I have the crew of the Normandy. 

This, mixed with improved gameplay, make ME2 an easy recommendation in its vanilla state. Modding is available, and there are a few mods that are potentially recommended (such as removing the hacking minigames) but that is up to player preference.

Pros:
Fantastic writing.
An impressive cast of uniquely written, interesting characters.
Well designed curated levels and missions, with interesting side content and a unique main story with a very solid ending that plays into the sequel.
Improved class diversity and skill management, and overall gameplay improvements from ME1.

Cons:
I have no immediate thoughts. I never ran into anything in ME2 that I felt was wrong, or needed improving. Every part of this game kept me interested, and I was devastated that it ended. Maybe that is the only downside - 26hrs wasn't enough.

To fix the "failed to initialize physics engine" issue for both ME2/3, follow this step by step guide.

Click "Start" --> "Control panel" --> Uninstall a program" locate PhysX in the list, --> "Right click PhysX" --> "Choose Repair"

If you don't have physx, download it from nVidia's website. This is an issue with AMD Graphics cards, as well. I spent so long pulling my hair until I found this fix. [url=https://answers.ea.com/t5/Mass-Effect-3/Game-fails-to-load-quot-Failed-to-initialize-the-physics-system/td-p/961834] Where I found the fix. [/url]

87447168.review:
I played the whole series on the PS3, and enjoyed it very much. ME2 was the best of the three, so when it became available on Steam, I decided to play it there, hoping that the scene load time would be faster on my modern PC. It turned out that this needed a mod, but that was OK.

What I discovered to my extreme disappointment after playing most of the way though was that my enjoyment of ME2 depended on several things:
- An import of an ME1 save with some specific choices.
- The ME2 DLC's.
- Additional specific choices into ME2.

 So I would have to:
- Buy all of the above additional stuff on Steam, which I already own for the PS3.
- Install and activate the DLC's. There is no good official documentation on how to do this. The UI built in to ME2 to do this no longer works. Some people claim to have done it successfully, but it is certainly not straightforward.
- Play though ME1 again, then import the save into ME2, and play through ME2 again to the same point, this time using a walk-through to guide my choices.

I'm just not up for all that.

My recommendation for others is to wait until the re-bundled series comes out on Steam, and then wait to see if others have found that the DLC problems that everyone has complained about are solved.

I have left comments open for now, in case someone has useful additional advice to offer. However, if the comments are abusive, I will disable them. Play nice, folks!

86650186.review:
[b][h1] "Expanding a Galaxy of World Building" [/h1][/b]


With the foundations laid by ME1, Mass Effect 2 takes all the errors of ME1 and refines them into an amazing polish. Gone are the repetitive nature of side quests and buggy Mako but arrive the lush and diverse range of different side quests that each has a planet full of personality. The best part about this sequel is the entire production of it, if ME1 is the risky experiment of Bioware then ME2 is the fulfillment of that dream coming into fruition. Many of the cut ideas from ME1 is realized in this installment from the interruption mechanic to the dynamic "Squad System" that has a new loyalty mechanic that will later affect your final mission. With the new loyalty mechanic, the game suggests you to take on missions that will acquire the trust of each crewmate. 

Each loyalty mission is full of interesting narratives and great character building especially 
[spoiler]Tali's[/spoiler] loyalty mission. Before the loyalty missions is the "Recruit Missions" which have dedicated soundtrack to hype you up for each of the crewmates your about to meet. One of the best recruit missions is the one in Omege where you recruit "Archangel" where as you go deeper into mercenary territory you hear stories of why they despise this so called "Archangel" and in the end you find out why and its a very nice reveal once you get there.

I think the final mission utilizes each decision you made for your crewmates throughout the game, this was lacking in the previous game leaving only two other crewmates be part of your squad in the final battle. But in this finale every character in your crew has a chance to have a spotlight and assist you in reaching the end, this is where the loyalty system kicks in because if you don't get the loyalty of some of these crewmates then you will arrive into dire consequences. Its a punishment that tells you to pay more attention to the extra content of the game instead of b-lining it into the finish line without a care for the world Bioware built for you.

The best quality of this game is its soundtrack and how it gave me goosebumps in the very end, the ending to this game is simply something that you must have to experience yourself. Play it through and experience the extra content and you will get the feelings I got when hearing the score in the ending. No other game today has got me into this thrill of just giving a speech while a heroic orchestra is in the background.

[b]"Came for the ass, stayed for the amazing story."[/b]

86233724.review:
Mass Effect 2 is a game I wanted to review after Mass Effect 1 but that was, like, a hundred years ago.

You play as John Shepard, or Jane Shepard if you’re not as cool as me. Months after the events of Mass Effect 1, Shepard and his homie brigade are patrolling space when they’re attacked by an actual space turd. The Space Turd fires its big space gun and messes up MY SHIP that was GIVEN TO ME by Anderson, my SPACE DAD. 

Shepard is launched into space and then dies, but its okay because Cerberus, the weird paramilitary human supremacist group from ME1, finds his gross charred chicken remains and uses actual space magic to revive him. Weird how the collectors didn’t just, like, you know, collect him instead of violently jettisoning him into space. 
And so begins another chapter in the life of Dirk Shepard, Intergalactic sex machine.
Also Cerberus took away my cool scar. Its gone, they healed it.

Mass Effect 2 moves away from Mass Effect in a lot of ways, focusing more on gunplay and shooting than the RPG aspects of its predecessor. People seemed to have problems with the gameplay of the first one, especially the Cuphead tutorial guy. I didn’t, I really liked Mass Effect, but I don’t mind Mass Effect 2. 
Loaning out from trends at the time, there is a big focus on cover and regenerating health, but you still have a chance to go nuts like you could in Mass Effect 1, its kind of nice how it, maybe unintentionally, lets you use the environments to your advantage, getting the jump on your opponents and dropping some powers on their dumbasses. At least on Normal you have more room to move around with your abilities. 
Also, they took away my cool scar. 

You have a new squad this time around with some returning faces. My best friend Garrus is back, but I had to replace my best friend Wrex with my wonderful son Grunt. I don’t think Garrus being back is a spoiler anymore, since he’s in a lot of the more recent promotional material. I like, mostly everyone. Jacob grew on me, turning from a piece of cardboard to someone I kind of felt like needed a hug. The big emphasis is on squad loyalty, so it helps when the characters aren’t unlikable puddles of sludge like in other games. 
Also, they took away my cool scar. 

I liked the story, even though it was kind of glue-eater at some points. Surprisingly a lot of the game is side missions, side missions that are mandatory if you want to get the best ending of the game. Bioware made a big deal about choices altering the outcome, but you have to actually be trying to get the worst ending. Its so easy to just paragon or renegade your way through most situations that its like, come on man, what’re you doing? 
Also they took away my cool scar. 

Even though its more streamlined, its nice that Mass Effect 2 continues to flesh out the series’ universe and lore. It does that thing that smelly people do where they go back on something and retcon, but there wasn’t anything too offensive, at least from what I noticed. You get a feeling that people actually live in this universe, and you kind of start to care about it as you go on. I was playing through Mass Effect recently and immediately moved on to Mass Effect 2 

So what are the downsides?
Well for one they took away my cool scar. Kind of pissed about that one.
I don’t remember the game being this glitchy, though it might just be because my operating system is literally from the future from when this game came out. Sometimes Shepard would fall out of bounds or phase through something he shouldn’t be able to. I also experienced a few crashes but strangely only when I was playing a DLC mission. Also, why did Shepard die? Couldn’t the Collectors just, you know, collect him? Hold on to him for two years until Cerberus breaks him out with a daring rescue mission? Somebody can probably correct me, but I don’t think Cerberus’ magical resurrection tech actually ever comes up again. 

I know its expensive, but you’d think they’d abuse it.
Also, I miss the Mako. People had a problem with it but I thought it was fun. That thing could scale a 90 degree cliff, I love that four wheeled lady wagon.

I got one more of these to go through, I haven’t played since it came out but I remember…Controversies. Still, It’ll be fun to complete the trilogy in one go. 

Mass Erect 2 gets 8 reloading for no reason out of 10. 

Male Koala have two penises. 
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7124597/] I’m Commander Shepard, and this is my favorite curator on Steam. [/url]

For those wondering about DLC Brois has learned in the last few days:
* As of early February 2021 due to potential exploits with the Steam Service keys have been hidden from users: Contact Steam Support for your keys. (And be nice to them, they are human too)
* Deluxe game does NOT come with all DLC.
* All DLC keys must be registered via the EA website or Origin for your goodies.
* All DLC not included in the Deluxe Edition must be purchased separately.
* All DLC must be downloaded from the EA website and installed one at a time.
* Access to the Cerberus Network (EA DRM) must be enabled to play the content you purchased each time on game startup.
* Consult a guide on the forums or on YouTube before you purchase. Creating an EA account, registering game and DLC keys, downloading and installing DLCs took about 2-3 hours in total before they can be accessed in game.

Gameplay, story, and graphics hold up quite well over the last 10 years.

85909880.review:
[b]Title: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1328670/Mass_Effect_Legendary_Edition/]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/url] - A Superior Remastered Compilation[/b]

The [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1328670/Mass_Effect_Legendary_Edition/]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/url] is a remarkable compilation of the entire original Mass Effect trilogy, fully remastered to deliver a superior gaming experience. When compared, there's no doubt that this remaster outshines the original Mass Effect 2. The enhanced graphics, reduced bugs, more recent development, and inclusion of all DLCs make it an easy recommendation. Purchasing the remaster grants access to the entire Mass Effect trilogy and its DLCs, all at a significantly lower cost than buying the original games and their DLCs separately. While I did experience slight micro-stuttering in hub areas, this seems to be a rare issue affecting only a small percentage of players. Despite this minor inconvenience, I still find no valid reason to favor the original over the remaster. For a detailed review of the remaster, you can refer to my post [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/recommended/1328670?snr=1_5_9__402]here[/url]. I highly recommend considering the remastered version for the overall better value it offers.

[b]Mass Effect 2 Editions on Steam[/b]

In addition to the Legendary Edition, Mass Effect 2 has two other editions available on Steam: the one you're currently reading about, and the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2362420/Mass_Effect_2_2010_Edition/]2010 Edition[/url]. A notable distinction is that the latter remains available for purchase, while the former has been delisted. Furthermore, the 2010 Edition simplifies the DLC acquisition process, automatically installing them without manual intervention, without even needing to buy them separately. If you previously owned the now delisted version, you should have the 2010 Edition in your library at no extra cost. The only drawback is that the 2010 Edition requires the EA launcher to run, though aside from this requirement, no other substantial changes have been introduced.

Mass Effect 2 stands as a true classic, revered as one of the finest accomplishments in the gaming industry. While its excellence is undeniable, it's not devoid of imperfections. As is often the case with sequels, it brings new marvels while leaving behind certain aspects from its predecessor.

Firstly, addressing its shortcomings, the game hosts a substantial collection of non-Steam DLCs and unresolved bugs. The mouse sensitivity issue persists, along with other minor glitches. To optimize your experience and encounter the game at its zenith, I recommend consulting my comprehensive [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2496769538]"All You Need" guide for Mass Effect 2[/url]. This guide encompasses solutions for known issues, guidelines for obtaining DLCs, and enhancements that preserve the game's original essence while elevating its visuals, including higher quality textures and 4K cinematics. It's important to acknowledge that my guide doesn't address all problems, particularly two unresolved issues. The first is a rare game-breaking bug involving character teleportation onto textures, forcing a reload of a previous save. The second issue pertains to sound misplacement, occasionally leading to auditory confusion about the source's location. Fortunately, this issue is not as dire as it could be in more competitive games.

The Mass Effect series has ingrained itself as one of my personal favorites. It boasts captivating characters, enthralling narratives, a captivating universe, and a richly detailed world.

Mass Effect 2 diverges notably from its predecessor. While it continues the overarching storyline, it distances itself from the traditional RPG elements that defined the first game. This sequel leans more towards action, a shift that harmonizes brilliantly with the story's progression. The limited exploration featured in the original—primarily on the Citadel and via the Mako vehicle—is entirely absent, a change that disappoints me despite the mixed reception of these features. Another transformation involves the transition from heat-based weapons to bullet-based weaponry. Although this adjustment is logical for gameplay, it lacks a coherent lore explanation within the game itself.

Mass Effect 2 commands admiration as a gaming masterpiece. Its meticulous execution prompts emotional investment in characters and narrative. This installment exhibits a darker tone in both visuals and storyline compared to its predecessor. The narrative remains as compelling and enigmatic as before, though it takes on a different dimension. Characters' individual narratives and the consequential choices they present resonate deeply. The game's side content and associated narratives further contribute to its remarkable depth. While I wasn't entirely content with the ending—albeit a subjective sentiment—this scarcely diminishes the overall experience.

The gameplay's seamless flow and immersive event progression often made me feel as if certain segments would never conclude—a sensation I welcomed wholeheartedly. The combat mechanics, including shooting mechanics, function impeccably, a stark departure from the first game's approach. Despite its merits, the implementation of powers left me somewhat unsatisfied, the global cooldown applied to all abilities remains a perplexing design choice, impacting my inclination to use them frequently.

It's curious how I find myself at a loss for words when endeavoring to elucidate my profound appreciation for something. This review, while comprehensive, barely scratches the surface of my sentiments. What I can confidently express is the sheer enjoyment I derived from Mass Effect 2. It represents a significant leap forward from the original game, irrespective of one's stance on its action-oriented direction. For me, it's become an essential part of an esteemed gaming collection, standing alongside cherished series favorites. I'm confident that indulging in this installment will lead to a profound and insatiable desire for more.

For achievement hunters: I believe it's worth noting that despite the in-game abundance of achievements, none are integrated with Steam—a similarity shared with the original game. Although I've earned all 62 of these achievements, their invisibility on Steam leaves them confined to [url=https://backloggery.com/games.php?user=ciocolici&search=Mass+Effect+2&console=&status=&unplayed=&rating=&region=&own=0&alpha=1]Backloggery[/url] and my personally composed [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/]Steam profile[/url] or [url=https://imgur.com/gallery/lZUlHms]screenshots[/url]. The achievements themselves were pretty hard to unlock. And I suggest you go that road only if you really love Mass Effect 2.

84855840.review: Mass Effect 2 has some weaknesses from it's predecessor. The thermal clip system is frustrating, I miss having a map to direct me around the areas, and the new scanning system is a little tedious and makes the galaxy feel smaller than it did in ME1. But in every other way it's a huge improvement. The powers and abilities have been significantly overhauled and simplified, making you progress faster and in more interesting ways. The plot is implemented into gameplay really well, giving you a sense of urgency you don't really expect in open-world RPGs and is written in a way that makes you want to complete quests in order to help out your party, rather than to just complete your codex. In almost every way an improvement over the last one.

84416549.review:
[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
In ME1 the main character prevented the immediate threat of a galaxy wide genocide however the galaxy is not yet out of the woods. ME2 brings you straight into the action; the Normandy is under attack by enemies that want to end your quest and let the Reapers rule again. You continue your epic quest in a much more refined game.

[H1]The good[/H1]
From the start ME2 shows it's a game from the next decade: the gameplay feels much more dynamic then the quite static ME. A cool feature is that you can continue playing with your character from ME1 by importing it (see below how to do that). The voice acting is great and I enjoyed the music much better. The RPG-lite system has been redesigned to a more action game with some RPG traces.

I read that some people disliked the minigames and yes, they can be tedious at times but I actually enjoyed them as they offer much more variety than the single system that was used in ME. I also found there is a mod to completely remove them but I did not use that as I wanted to experience the game as it was meant to be played except with better graphics :-).

The game gives some freedom in the sense that you can pick most of the time what system you would like to explore: however when you find something interesting you then get a scripted mission. At first I did not like that so much however this provided the designers a lot of control of what you experience and it helps a lot with the story telling so in the end I believe this was the right choice. 

The Codex deserves special mention: there is a lot to read, see and hear about the universe. Most of it is presented when required during gameplay - and ME2 still maintains the right balance of not to overwhelming you with lore, yet if you want even more information it is all there. The closest game I can think of that also has this is AC: Origin or Odyssey. 

There is now a general research option that provides the whole squad with more bonusses if you are willing to find and spend resources of course. It is a good decision to know have you switch easily between various ammo (after you have research it) compared to the confusing ME1 inventory system.

The Overlord DLC started OK and became quickly one of my most favourite DLCs I've ever played: it's creepy, emotional and is presented so well. It's just amazing!

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
The game is from 2010 and unless you really would like to relive that time in terms of graphics and videos I would strongly recommend to use at least a few mods to make the game feel and play a lot better. Find the hard work of fans at [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/] Nexus Mods [/url]. However, be sure to install all DLC and non-texture mods before you start installing graphics mode otherwise you might run into graphic issues.

Also the ME2 config tool does no longer works - you need that tool to tell ME2 where the save games of ME1 are located. Instead follow this advice (thanks to [url=https://answers.ea.com/t5/Mass-Effect-2/PC-Importing-a-save-file-from-Mass-Effect-1/td-p/751184] Holger1405 [/url]:
[quote=Holger1405]Navigate to your "Documents\BioWare\Mass Effect 2\Save" folder and create a folder named "ME1" (Without the quotes) inside the "Save" Folder.
After you finished ME1, copy the Mass Effect Saves from the Mass Effect save folder ("Documents\BioWare\Mass Effect\Save") into the "ME1" folder you created.
Now ME2 should "see" your ME1 characters.[/quote]

There are now achievements on a separate screen but there are none for Steam. It's probably the age of the game - I'm not too concerned about it but some people might not like this so much.

The game runs at 60FPS on my RTX3070; most likely this is a limitation of the game engine. It did not bother me much as the engine delivers all the action well but after having played Doom Eternal at 144 FPS I had to adjust myself a little :-).

Over the course of your adventure you are able to collect various weapons - it would have been better to also see the stats instead of just a vague description. It might to do that they wanted to dumb down the system a bit so it is more accessible.

I experienced one crash - but I'm unsure whether it was the game or because of the texture mod. I had to restart Windows to continue. As with all games I would advise to frequently use quick save (F5) to prevent too much gameplay lose although there is an auto save system that generally works OK. During Jacob's loyalty mission there were some issues with clipping but nothing too serious.

[H1]Summary[/H1]
This game came out in 2010 and with some mods it is still very playable in 2021. The game is much more accessible than the first game and the story writing and world building is great and just continues to build on the foundation that was laid out with ME1. It's good that you can import your old character and choices you made in the first game will affect your play through in ME2 to a certain degree. I enjoyed visiting old places to see how they are now (like for example the citadel) or meeting up with my old party members. 
The music and sound effects have been greatly improved and there is no MAKO anymore (although they added some horrible drone instead but you hardly use that - it's mostly used during firewalker missions which you can skip IMHO). All in all, even now there is no reason not to play this game.

Note 1: you can get all the DLC from the [url=https://help.ea.com/en-us/help/faq/dlc-for-classic-games/] EA website [/url]. Don't bother with the Origin launcher as it will not download any of them even if it states you can download or add it to the queue. Your browser may give a warning but that's because the DLCs are all .exe files (note it seems you can only download four files at a time - so wait until the first four have finished and then download the other ones). You then have to click on each file to have them manually installed. It's a bit of work but at least you get all the extra DLCs :-) - I'm a bit confused because at the EA store / Origin app (that does not seem to work) you still have to pay for it?

Note 2: when you get to the point you have a mission with IFF please make sure you have completed everything you want to do in the game before continuing.

83594527.review:
[h1]Las aventuras del comandante Shepard pt. 2[/h1]

[b][u]AVISO SPOILERS DE:[/u]
Mass Effect 1 y sus desiciones.[/b]
[i]Dos meses pasaron de la batalla contra el Soberano en la Ciudadela, el comandante Shepard y su fiel tripulacion, abordo de la Normandia siguen dando caza a las geth restantes por los sistemas del espacio de la Ciudadela cuando son atacados por una nave no identificada, El combate lleva a que la tripulacion deba abandonar la nave y somos los encargados de asegurar a toda la tripulacion o a gran parte de ella dando nuestra vida a cambio y quedando a la deriva en el espacio.
Dos años mas tarde, en una base del grupo Cerberus despertaremos para encontrarnos que seguimos con vida gracias a que ellos nos restauraron, con muchas mejoras fisicas y un viejo conflicto latente. La amenaza Geth sigue presente y, segun Cerberus cuentan con ayuda de nuevos y mas temibles aliados. Nos pondran al mando de una nueva nave Normandia con mejor tecnologia y algunos de los restos de nuestra vieja tripulacion para detener esta amenaza.[/i]

Lo primero que vamos a notar a la hora de empezar una nueva partida, al menos en mi caso que importe mi save del primer juego, es que la mayoria de desiciones que se importan son en su mayoria de las ultimas 2 misiones.

Graficamente es muchisimo mas superior a su antecesor, contamos con animaciones que reaccionan al entorno y los diarios de las misiones principales tienen animaciones holograficas o de video que no tenia anteriormente.
Los cambios no son solamente graficos sino que la interfaz y controles son diferentes, ahora tambien podremos esprintar sin la necesidad de estar en combate.

En su jugabilidad lo primero que encontramos es que ahora la municion tiene un contador y no es un medidor de calor como antes, permitiendo que te puedas agotar un arma y tengas que pasar a otra para poder seguir combatiendo, cosa que se agradece porque en Mass Effect 1 podias pasarte el juego usando 1 solo arma, ya no existen las granadas y se agrego un tipo de arma grande que tiene varias versiones tanto comprables como desbloqueables si las encontramos en el mundo. Tampoco encontraremos 8 modelos  diferentes de un tipo de arma como antes, de milagro si hay 2 a 3 versiones de cada tipo de fusil, pistola, subfusil, francotirador o escopeta.
En cuanto a las mejoras tenemos tanto como para el daño de las armas como el daño tecnologico o biotico del peloton, sino que tambien de vida y armadura. Tambien la propia Normandia se puede mejorar para que sea mas potente y en mi caso lo que mas agradeci para la exploracion que voy a detallar mas adelante.
Como antes, la moneda de cambio siguen siendo los creditos, mas escasos en esta entrega pero se agregaron nuevos recursos para comprar las mejoras. estos recursos son 4 y se recolectan con la exploracion planetaria y tambien podemos encontrar contenedores por los mapeados.

Para hablar de la exploracion planetaria, en primer medida ya no se usa el Mako, simplemente nos acercamos al planeta nos dira que abundancia de recurso tiene y podemos ir escaneando el terreno y van a salir lecturas de que recurso es rico en esa zona y lanzando una sonda lo recolectamos, cabe aclarar que estas sondas hay que comprarlas con credito al igual que el combustible para movernos entre sistemas solares. Tambien puede ser que se detecten anomalias que si decidimos lanzar una sonda en esa anomalia podamos hacer una incursion terrestre y tener una mini-mision para conseguir armas o mas recursos.
Tambien en algunas misiones hay un Mako nuevo que parece un aerodeslizador que permite mas verticalidad que antes a la hora de realizar estas misiones que sinceramente son bastante pocas aunque muy entretenidas.

Ahora lo que vamos a tener presente siempre durante el juego y en nuestra nave, son los compañeros o aliados, en comparacion con el anterior, podremos reclutar hasta 10 aliados con sus diferentes razas tanto alienigenas como humanos. El maximo jugable siguen siendo 2 pero, ahora cuentan con nuevas habilidades bastante mas simple que antes, ya no necesitaremos tener un experto en tecnologia y electronica para desbloquear todo cosa que me molesto mucho, ahora puedo llevar a quien me caiga mejor y nada mas.
Tambien introducen el sistema de fidelidad, que la unica forma de conseguirlo es haciendo la mision que cada miembro nos pida, es siempre una mision, por lo general que dura 1 hora aproximadamente y cabe destacar que son bastante entretenidas y le dan muchisima mas historia a nuestros compañeros. Cuando nuestros compañeros sean fieles desbloquean un nuevo estilo para su traje y una rama de habilidad especial.

En lo que a las misiones respecta, se parece mucho al primero, casi diria que no hay muchos cambios y son mas detalles, cambiaron el sistema de hackeo con 2 nuevos puzzles, la derivacion para las puertas, que es un memory bastante simple y un pirateo para las terminales, este ultimo el mas complicado ya que hay que encontrar 3 lineas de codigos de colores que tenemos que ir comparando al momento mientras llueven lineas de codigo y tambien lineas trampa que si las pasamos por encima tendremos que reiniciar o en algunos casos perder ese recurso directamente.
Tambien continua el sistema de Virtud y Rebeldia, si bien siguen sirviendo para lineas de dialogos adicionales para solucionar o complicar algunas situaciones, tambien afectaran a las cicatrices de Shepard, siendo virtud la que lo curara y, creo, rebeldia supuestamente lo daña aun mas. Digo creo porque jugue siempre con virtud y se curo por completo, tambien con una mejora de la nave podemos curarlas independientemente del estilo de juego. Tambien entre cinematicas tendremos opciones de las mismas a modo de Quick Time Event y aunque no lo parezca pueden cambiar mucho la historia dependiendo si elegimos actuar o no. EJ con Spoiler: [spoiler]Cuando estaba por rescatar a Garrus, tenia la opcion de incapacitar a un soldado con rebeldia y no lo hize, ese soldado tomo una nave y le disparo hasta casi matarlo y lo dejaron con unas cicatrices hermosas durante todo el juego.[/spoiler]

Como era de esperar de Bioware, mejoro lo que hizo con Mass Effect y lo llevo a otro nivel, donde mejoro todos los aspectos de su juego anterior, quitando errores o fallos jugables que podia tener y dejo su segunda entrega en un buen punto. Solo me queda embarcarme en la tercera y ultima entrega de esta trilogia y ver que me voy a encontrar pero de momento el camino empezo bien y siguio mucho mas arriba de donde comenzo.

Easily my favorite of the Mass Effect franchise.  it sports a darker more roguish atmosphere than its predecessor with the only complaints I can think of  being the occasional glitch that makes the node connecting mini game a bit more difficult as the node will un-select the moment you select its match leaving you bouncing back and forth between the two in a game of cursor pong.  Other than that the game performs just as flawless as its console counterpart. Rumor has it there's a remake in the works but for those of you who, like me, aren't sporting high end gaming rigs this version will do just fine to get your mass effect fix. 

I do have to warn you though, The DLC's didn't work for me when I bought the digital deluxe edition.  An odd Cerberus Network  connection error kept popping up  so I had to use my EA login to go to the Origins website and redeem my product keys there, then download the DLC's individually from  EA. It did fix the cerberus network connection problem though as it connected just fine afterwards. You just can't use your product keys in the game itself when you have this issue. It is pretty inconvenient but bear in mind this could just be a steam issue or it could be the result of the game getting pretty old. They cant keep the servers open forever so workarounds are expected. 

All in all I still Give it a 10/10.

The game is WORTH IT.

PROS:
 - The story is still great as ever.
 - The world-building is as good as the first game, you'll be able to understand the story without playing the first game by I don't recommend playing ME2 before ME1.
 - Your crew members in the game cannot be more well-developed than this. I would've bought this game for the characters alone.
 - The main protagonist (Shepard) is as badass as you can get.
 - Combat is really good, and definitely an upgrade from the first game. Thermal clips, in my opinion, is a good addition since I don't want to wait 5-10 seconds to be able to shoot my gun again, but to each their own.
 - Loyalty quests are amazing. All of the loyalty quests are memorable.
 - The biotic attacks are so much better when compared to the previous game.
 
CONS:
 - You have to buy the DLC from Origin separately.
 - There are some glitches that caused me to reload a save. 
 - A lot of quests boil down to Eclipse, Blue Suns, and Blood Pack members swarming out of a door.
 - *Nitpick* The sprinting in ME1 is better than in ME2.

Story - 9/10
Characters - 11/10
Combat - 7/10

(The DLC stuff is still terrible though, if you want to have your game and DLC in one place buy it on Origin. If you don't mind having your game on Steam and buying the DLC from Origin that can work too.)

82914524.review:
A light rpg with many creative ideas turned into generic cover based shooter with most mechanics simplified or removed. That is what mass effect 2 is compared to mass effect and i don't like it. There you have it the short answer of the review.
The review may contain few minor/heavy spoilers so beaware.
Changed it into reccomened after playing and actually enjoying me3. My negatives still stand if me3 didnt exist the review would still be a negative. If i had to name few positive stuff about the game quickly it would be: characters,their stories and you get to see the characters conclusion on me3.

MAIN REASON: GAMEPLAY
-----------------
The main and most disappointing fact about this game is its gameplay and simplfication of mechanics from first game. I loved mass effect 1. By no means it was perfect. It had its shortcomings but despite that it was a great game which had great ideas /concept that it wanted to achieve but couldn't for its time. Now when a series receives a sequel its is expected that it improves mechanics from previous game and also fix the shortcomings that holded the previous game back instead of entirely removing them. As a sequel mass effect 2 is a massive disappointment. It removes almost everything that made the first game great or simplfies them. And also totally axes first game's ambitious ideas instead of improving them and making them reach their full potential. This is what i call taking the easy way out by taking out things that were criticised instead of fixing/improving them. They also made every single feature that were taken from first game extremely linear and simple. A change that defeats the entire point why i liked the first game. I liked the first game for its in-depth rpg mechanics such as stats,upgrades and open ended nature of the game such as mission design,level strucure. The tacticallity of the first game is also something i loved. Squad combat was very open ended and player had full control over the squad. Now mass effect 2 makes level/mission design extremely linear. Missions now always tend to have a single linear path which player can execute. 
Player Level stats are also made very simple/linear and more combat oriented rather then letting players choose if they would like to play defense or attacking. Level stats are now broken down to few segments and 3 of them are literally weapon upgrades from mass effect 1. Now i don't know if stats are different compared to new save or imported save. But i won't worry about that as a review is a personal experience/thoughts of someone. Inventory system is also gone. Now you only get to change your gear before entering a single linear path or before starting the mission itself. That too only weapons. Amours and such can be only managed through personal office of shepard. There is also no way to manage crew mates armours. Now i will be honest i never changed my crew mates iconic armours on mass effect 1 only bought/used upgraded edition of their armour. But now only way to do that is to find a upgrade laying around on those linear mission and click few menus. See how much sense of tacticallty and player freedom is lost on this game. On the first game even the order you did the missions in matterd and here missions only tend to have single path/outcome with occasional changes to the story of certain mission but still using same linear path. The linearity of missions,simplification of level stats and removal of inventory system are the biggest downgrades/flaws of this game as a sequel. Squad combat is also way more simple now and favours more fast paced combat instead of slow tactical combat first game had. Some squad commands such as "hold postion" is also gone. Moving squad members no longer pauses the game like first game where player could admire his surrounding and throughfully move them. Squad mates are also very op and stupid at times making stupid decision themself instead of sticking with the leader. The entire nature of the game is made very linear in order to fit into this generic cover based fast paced shooter formula instead of light rpg direction first game took. Side missions only either last two secs and are WORSE fetch quests then first game. They had this golden opportunity to fully achieve their goals from first game by improving the shortcomimgs of first game but instead they took the easy way out and totally shifted their focus. Which resulted in a change of series's identity i do not like. Instead of improving the emptiness sometimes presented on open ended missions of mass effect they made the missions linear and worse. Missions that have generic cover based action segments instead of epic boss battles first game had. Missions are so linear and scripted that offers little to no control of player. Instead of delivering high quality side content they deliverd even worse side content. Instead of improving the stats system they made it even worse and simple/linear. Instead of fixing/optimizing the inventory they totally got rid of it.Instead of making the space exploration better they also got rid of it and turned most planets into none exploreable resource hub to upgrade Normandy. Instead of making the vehicle segments better or maybe giving us control of mini space ship they entirely got rid of it. Exploration wasn't perfect on mass effect 1. Planets felt empty and most were used for fetch quests. But i still loved the sense of exploration they gave. Instead of improving that they got rid of exploration all together. And gave planets even worse purpose. At least fetch quests on planets had good stories on first game, but here resource collecting aka new purpose of planets is very boring and bland. As you can already notice how lazy this sequel is. They got rid of good things of first game in the efforts of making the game more causal friendly and they got rid of meh things from first game in lazyness and to find a escape from the work that would be required to fix/improve those features. As a result of all the things mentioned above this game turns into a extremely boring game with missions being linear and having very scripted paths. Getting rid of almost all the features of the first game or simplifying them also resulted in a game which literally defeats the purpose and identity of the series and takes it into a direction i do not like.
SECONDARY REASON:STORY
------------------------
The story of mass effect 2 is also very lackluster with few crew mates story being actually good.Most crew characters were very unintresring expect few like thane,salarian scientist,jack.I already liked talia and garrus from first game.Their dialogues were more then enough on me1 to make them likeable.Their missions also don't add up much to their already existing character.The plot of this game is very bland and has very little purpose to exist.it felt like a giant side/dlc story to the overall repear threat story of the series.There are also very few plottwist and story is predictable.Collectors being prothean and all that Cerberus feels very irreverent to me.That being said whole story and plot of the game is pretty meh imo with some likeable characters.
Overall Mass effect 2 is a horrible sequel with most good things from me1 being stripped away or made simple/linear and also has a very lackluster story.I wanted to explain story abit more and why i dislike it but couldn't because of review limit but the gameplay changes and removal are more then enough to dislike this game for me.

82856359.review:
I came back to this game after a long absence and a change of computer. I re-downloaded it from Steam. I had originally purchased a lot of the DLC that came with it, and I thought, naively, that it all would come back with the game. Of course it didn't, so I went to the unsecured site recommended by EA and re-downloaded the DLC and thought, problem solved. Alas, how wrong was I, gentle reader. 

The game would  not load from the resume button. This was because it did not recognise that the DLC was, in fact, installed. The fault, it turned out, was mine: I had not followed the instructions in this extremely helpful post: 

https://steamcommunity.com/app/24980/discussions/0/1742229167209908670/

It's not just a case of downloading and installing the DLC - it is essential to download the zipped "giveme2entitlements_v2" file and run it. After that, the game and the DLC worked perfectly well.

In switching platforms from Steam to Origin, EA seriously compromised my DLC and the DLC of thousands of other players. And while I've been able to fix my game, I'm sure there will be other players out there who aren't prepared to click on unsecured links to get the repair job they need, because a corporation broke their game and doesn't give a rat's rectum. This kind of commercial chicanery gives games companies a bad name. The solution that has been provided is largely the work of dedicated gamers and not the companies who created the mess.

I love Mass Effect 2. Bits of it are silly to the power of ten, but it has a brilliant plot line and a  sense of humour.  I like the settings, the 'star trek meets grunge" vibe of the whole thing. I'm pleased I'm able to play it properly again. So I've changed my recommendation.

82633633.review:
Honestly this is gonna be a review about what to do when you get the game. It's a pain but let me save you the trouble:

1) buy the game here OR on the origin store (whichever is cheaper)
2) Download Origin
3) press "Origin" in top right and select "Redeem product code"
4) Redeem either both Cerberus and the ME2 key OR just the Cerberus key (if you installed the main game on steam the DLC should load to your files regardless)
5) Scroll down in the Origin browser under "Mass Effect 2" - "extra content" and select all the items that are available for free, you have already paid for them and that was what the Cerberus code was for.
6) If you want: BUY the DLC Bundle and install that too.
7) Load the game and log in using *THE SAME* EA Games account as the one you used on the Origin store.
8) enjoy your time playing the game

Side note: You will have to log in EVERY time you play the game because it does not save your credentials, that is not a bug.

The only downside to Mass Effect 2 (and others) is that the fighting is just a series of you hiding behind conveniently placed  barriers and walls, which makes it quite repetitive at times. This, however, doesn't overshadow the fact the game is great all around. Some of the best pieces of gameplay in the ME series is what happens in dialogue; such as punching women in the face for making disingenuous assertions, pushing people out of windows, and the snarky comments and input your compatriots will make throughout the game is definitely worth it.

I would say my 'biggest issue' with the game is the Paragon / Renegade options. Instead of having the typical 'Good and evil' options, you have paragon and renegade. These aren't good/ bad options per se, but they give you more felxibility in how your character is played. Either 'By the book' or a Dirty Harry anti-hero. That's how it worked in the first game. However, in 2 - 3, they become less ambiguous and more good/ bad. And if you go down a renegade path, you become less Dirty Harry, and more Lev Beria. Your choices become more sadistic, and they leave negative consequences down the line. Also, you get red-eyes if you go full-renegade.

Apart from that. It's a perfectly flawed game. I recommend getting this game on origin with all the DLCs, if you can. Adds good weapons, armour, quests and squad members.

81836338.review:
If you haven't played the Mass Effect trilogy, you're missing out on some of BioWare's best work, but if you're looking to get into it now, I would recommend just getting it on console.

The PC port of ME2 is full of game breaking bugs, my personal favorite of which is where you randomly glitch into terrain and can't get out without using the NOCLIP console command or (if you haven't downloaded the tool SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED to add NoClip as a hotkey because of how pervasive this bug is) restart the mission. There's also a host of graphical issues (Though I don't think any quite as bad as the Shadow People glitch in the ME1 port).

The DLC for ME2 is fantastic. On the console version of the game, it's include. On the PC version, if you want it to work you have go through Origin. Upside, if you have ME2 installed through Steam, Origin will automatically install your DLC and do your game updates to your Steam install so you won't need to try and shuffle files anywhere.

Downside: The Cerberus Network (through which your DLC is verified in-game) cannot remember that you're logged in, and can't see that you're currently logged into Origin. The login screen for the Cerberus Network poorly optimized for PC use. Tab doesn't work, so you have to manually click each field. The password field has a hard-coded character limit that is most likely shorter than your Origin password, so if you want to actually be able to USE your DLC (only $24.99 on Origin, and no the Digital Deluxe Steam version does NOT include it!), you'll have to change your password on Origin to something short enough to fit within the character limit in the game.

Don't like the janky mouse and keyboard control scheme and want to use a gamepad? Jokes on you, the menus use the gamepad like a mouse, and while you can technically use a controller, there are no settings and no support for this console game to use one.

It is one of the worst PC ports I've dealt with, and cannot recommend anyone spend money on it, even on sale (Especially since you have to go to EA and fork over more money to them to get the actual full experience, that again, was INCLUDED on the console version of the game).

So either get the trilogy on console, or wait and hope the Remastered edition is less of a cluster.

Wow!
I decided to play ME1 first and I WISH I HAD NOT DONE THAT.

This is a better game. Smoother movement, improved cover system, simplified inventory, it just goes on! I had to PUSH myself to finish the first game but the story and consequences carrying over to the new game made it feel worth it.... UNTIL THE FIRST CUTSCENE!!

The beginning masterfully lets me remake my character if i wanted to make any tweaks to my look/class and I am super impressed by the evolution of the world! MORE ALIENS!! I love that! The new designs are so neat and i really enjoy talking to everyone, not just the crew!

Regarding customization, there has been a give-and-take: The library of weapons of ME1 is gone. Poof. Instead, the inventory remains in weapon boxes where you customize a loadout much like in Battlefield4. While this streamlines the entire loadout process, i happen to LOVE stat comparison, weapon balance, and collecting / reading about the manufactures and fun marketing materials. The armor library has also been replaced with customizing a single suit with different parts you earn throughout your playthrough. Overall, I admit these all to be improvements. (well back to injustice2/destiny2 for my gear collection fix)

[the following was added after I beat the game]

okay
This is a superior game. In almost every department this game proves smoother, simpler, and very very well thought through. The final battle was a bit too easy but I took the time to upgrade and collect everything I possibly could. Even so, I never really bothered to use the heavy weaponry despite my choice to play a soldier class! I prefer to begin games on the "hard" or "Veteran" difficulty and then dial it back as needed, still, this was too easy. My squad always had one biotic and one engineer which gave me he flexibility to handle just about any situation. The powers are balanced and recharge times never feel crippling. The adrenaline ability is such a crutch, it turns tense moments into shooting galleries and I found myself trying my best not to use it at all. 

To anyone struggling: stay behind cover, gather a full team, level yourself up into an unstoppable force and the game will be a breeze.

9/10 
This is one of Bioware's best!

Story

The story is master-tier, dialogue is in your control, as in you can choose which voice lines you want your character to use in a conversation and the choices you make have consequences. It is recommended to play the entire trilogy to get a better perspective of it though, especially the first game.

Gameplay

When starting the game you get the option to customize your character or use the default skin. You can also pick your character's class that enhance different areas of the gameplay by giving you different powers to use and different weapons.

Because you and your other two squad members fighting by your side during missions have powers, you can do a little more than shooting. You can pause time in-game, select a target and then choose a certain power that you and/or your squadmates will use. Although this game tends to be a bit of a cover shooter, there are means that could give you mobility. However, cover shooter or not, in my opinion, gameplay feels great. It can offer a bit of trouble considering that the enter cover and sprinting are the same button, sometimes it makes it easier to transition.

Progress

Progression has you upgrade your character's abilities as well as your squadmates' abilities via skill trees and you and your squad's equipment.
10 out of fucking 10 from me.

80276565.review:
The consensus on the internet and in the gaming press is that Mass Effect 2 is the best entry in the series.  As mentioned in my review of Mass Effect, I think the first game is the best.  Let's break down the pros and cons of its sequel.

Pros:

More engaging combat.  The combat in Mass Effect was generally too easy and sometimes superfluously easy.  The combat in the sequel required more care decision-making.  I prefer games that require some thought and effort, even if some of the hilarity is lost.  

Some graphical upgrades.  Tech marches on.

No Ashley and Kaiden as squadmates.  Those two were boring.  

The story structure allows you a great deal of freedom, even more so than the first game.  

You do not storm copy-pasted bases, freighters, and underground complexes dozens of times over; environments are unique.  

Cons:

No Mako and no exploration of planets.  The level design is very corridor-based and restrictive.  

No more inventory; you pick what weapons you want; you can get permanent upgrades through research; no more applying different upgrades to individual pieces of equipment.  The various vendors around the galaxy have extremely limited wares and you cannot sell excess gear to build up your space bank account.  

Likewise, the skill system got massively nerfed; each squadmate gets only two abilities; in the first game they could have a half-dozen or so.  Not only that, but if a squadmate uses an ability, there is a cooldown for all abilities, not just that one (granted, the cooldowns are much faster than in the first game). 

Ammo.  The first game did not use it.  This one does.  The codex in the first game explained how the guns worked; I was cool with that.  

You may have noticed that the cons I point out are ones that affect the RPG elements of the game.  While I understand tweaking RPG elements, removing or massively downgrading them seems a poor choice to me.  

On balance, Mass Effect 2 is still a great game; most of the good things from the original carry on here; excellent characters, fantastic music, some terrific writing, and so on.  However, in an effort to streamline the game, some of the RPG complexity was sadly lost. 

If you liked the original, hang onto your save file and import it into Mass Effect 2.

Mass Effect 2 added and optimized mechanics the previous game had while also directed the game to be more casual friendly. Traversal became more efficient despite still being a game with a long playtime. No more fetch quests/sidemissions definitely encouraged me to complete the game to the fullest. When it comes to story driven RPG games with multiple outcomes I prefer going blindly rather than looking up for necessary informations outside the game, Mass Effect 2 did well in that regard. Just by following the story, interacting with NPCs, you could tell what you have to do. ME2 did its best maximize the playable areas potential to make sure you don't miss out things.

Resources collecting and hacking are introduced in this sequel. Due to the addition of a proper upgrades mechanics, the resource collecting is quite a necessity. Although I think there should be more varied ways to collect them. I quite liked the minigames for hacking as it isn't really time consuming and never felt like a chore to do because its present in missions/assignments. 

The upgrades mechanism is a great addition because it effectively accomodate your squad's preferred playstyle. Like I mentioned before they perfected/optimized the gameplay in the previous game and it applied to the third person shooter gameplay with the perks it offers in your squad combat. Weaponries is now packaged with more casuality as they have removed the weapon stats and added effects instead. Despite that, you still can feel the difference between each weapons you use.

Now onto the story. Its Bioware's Mass Effect. Always captivating, always a great experience. Once again proven to be serious in narrating its franchise's lore which they have designed in the previous game with its close to home social issues, politics, and diversity. The story continues where it lefts off in the end of the previous game with your Commander Shepard. So don't play this if you haven't played the first game yet.

79316777.review:
Mass Effect 2 is a fantastic sequel to Mass Effect, and one of my favorite Sci-Fi RPG games of all time.
Taking place two years after the events of the first Mass Effect, a new and mysterious enemy has emerged.

Mass Effect 2 improves on everything the first game did so well. The story gets much more interesting with some great twists and character development. The relationships between characters is much more important in this game too. There are real consequences and the end of the game can be very different depending on the choices you make. 

The combat mechanics have been widely enhanced and the controls are improved. The game also looks much better visually. There is a lot more content in this game when compared to the first, there is a lot that you can do and none of the side quests were boring for me. Some side quests are extremely short and only require you to talk to several people, but even these side quests are interesting because even the smallest most insignificant characters are so interesting with their own problems and you often get to deal with them how you like.

Not too mention you can carry over your original mass effect save to this game so that the decisions from you made from the first game carry over into this one. Bringing their benefits... and consequences. And when you beat this game, you can carry over this save to Mass Effect 3. And the ending to Mass Effect 2 is considered by many who played through it, including myself, as one of the best endings in video game history. While these games are mainly setting up the grand finale of Mass Effect 3, their own stories are still very grand in scale and never let me down.

Mass Effect is a great accomplishment for the gaming industry and Bioware should be very proud of what they created here

79244822.review:
[b]Mass Effect 2 | ★★★★★[/b]
                                                                 
A terrific exploration in my book. Mass Effect 2 manages to expand the deeper world that the first game already serves. This entry focused on a journey, where you'd assembly a high skilled team scattered around the galaxy. Each individual has an interesting story that makes you value them for their vital role in upcoming battles.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Improved foundation of combats from the first game but still doesn't separated them very far. I liked how they compressed the upgrading system which is overwhelming on the first one, they make them straight to the point which turn them easier to use here. Character Actions and Decisions choices were always straightforward, which makes your intention very easy to spot either it was good or bad.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
Visual that doesn't look like it came out from 2010. The details were night & day compared to its predecessor. However, there are noticeable size decreased of levels, which make the free roam very shorter than the first one. There are also some few glitches where you get stuck in the air if somehow you walked in a wrong place which kinda ruin some immersion in some part.

[b]Story:[/b]
The main narrative was straight to the point and can be easily explained briefly. It was like the first Avenger movie where you're Captain America and trying to recruit each hero for a great cause. However, that was not what make Mass Effect great. It was their storytelling and how they portray a non-existent world to be comfortably real at is it.

[b]Overview:[/b]
It was an experience to remember. There is a lot of great comedic timing that makes me laugh off guard, A lot of moment that makes you cared, A bunch of choices that make you think "what if?", and a suspense grand finale that only Bioware knows how to drop.

78746246.review:
I played this one again after the disappointment of Andromeda. I wanted to remember what a good game was like and how the same developer could literally forget how to make masterpieces. People come and go and development teams change and then you end up with shit. But, for a moment in time nearly nine years to the date of this writing, perfection was created at Bioware studios. I never thought I could like a game so much with no jump button, but in all aspects the game delivers in droves: story-telling, character development, choice with consequences, and deep engaging writing.

I envy you if you haven't played the game yet--if you're considering buying and playing it for first time. The emotional impact of my first playthrough was unmatched by all the subsequent. For its time, the writing and depth were also equally unmatched. It's all B scifi stuff of course, but it works really well if you let it. Trek fans looking to play captain of their own ship, this is the game for you. I'm surprised they haven't been remastered yet--seems like developers could still get a lot of milk from these cows.
