78265262.review:
Great side characters, multiple endings and a great story to follow, sounds good right? Well first you'll have to get past the fact that basically nothing has stayed the same since the first game, almost all of it for the better.
Taking on every hurdle the galaxy can throw at you all while not even knowing who you can trust or if your friends have your back, and that's what makes it memorable, the drive to do what you can without knowing who or what you'll lose along the way.
Overall - 8.5/10 (A great story, I could honestly say it's the highlight of the trilogy since the 3'rd one is so heavily influenced by the first 2 that you have to play all of them to truly enjoy it.
Story - 8/10 (This trilogy is made by its characters and law, and this game is where most of it is learnt and even built)
Characters (None of them are the same, even the ones from the first have changed -- having gone through hell during and after the first game, and the cherry on top is you being able to help them deal with it)
Graphics - 7.6/10 (WAY better than the first, but still rough around the edges at points. Still really good)
Performance - 10/10 (Old games get good performance, deal with it)
Movement - 6/10 (A weird mix of being better and worse than the original. You get used to it, but overall it's not that good, since shift is used to interact, sprint, AND take cover. You tell me how that gets annoying...)
Combat - 7/10 (Overall it's better than the first one and generally enjoyable, but there are some aspects that I wish they didn't change)
Make your decisions wisely, and remember that this trilogy will punish you for every choice you make, good and bad, each with a different ending. So decide what you do knowing that you at least tried, but there's nothing gained with giving something up first.

78146391.review:
Face Imports to ME3.

I found a way to fix the face import bug that is very simple.  Just use the gibbed save editor and only delete the face code.  I spent hours trying to recreate my character but this fixed it perfectly.  By removing the face code ME3 will import based on the vectors, not the wrong face code.

---

For me this was the weakest of the series.  I disliked the direction of working with Cerberus and I honestly didn't like the feel of trying to recruit random people around the galaxy to do a suicide mission.  It took me until about half-way to realize what was going on.   


Just understand that you are recruited for a suicide mission to save the galaxy and it will make more sense.  The first time through it wasn't clear.  And I had a hard time with recruiting certain people such as prisoners who seemed unstable.  Also I had spent a huge amount of time stopping this terrorist organization in the first game.  So it was a bit of a stretch for me to just up and run with them.  The game turns a corner about half way through and finally comes into itself. 

Personally I felt this was the weakest game in the series in terms of story line.  It also is frustrating they spent a huge amount of time focusing on recruiting people yet in ME3 you don't have any of these people as crew members.  It made no sense to me to focus so heavily on developing these characters to abandon them.

--- ME3 Review ---


I don't have ME3 on steam but it is incredible both in game play and character development all the way until the very very end.  The game itself plays as a story line based on all your choices from the first two games.  The end of ME3 is garbage as I was actually totally confused on choices being given that didn't even make sense to me.  I would just recommend this.  As soon as you see the child they show from the beginning of ME3 foreshadowing, end the game.  Just turn it off and make up your own ending.  I had to come to the conclusion of rewriting the story line for ME3 as there was no choice my Shepard would have taken based on the choices given. Nothing that you had achieved really mattered and the choices offered weren't discussed in the game world.  I was literally sitting there thinking, what is going on and what are these choices?  It made no sense to me.

*Spoilers*
I had brought peace between the Geth and Quarians.  Tali mourned the loss of Legion.  The Geth had been upgraded to fully individuals and were working with the Quarians. None of this though highly relevant to the ending is even mentioned.  I had done so much that flew in the face of that last dialog as I never cared one way or the other about machines life versus chemical biological life.  It was irrelevant to my Shepard through the entire series.  I am a spectre, an alliance soldier and I bring peace to the galaxy.  ALL LIFE.  Not this garbage ending.

In my story I decided it ends by sending an energy wave through the galaxy that disconnects the reapers from each other.  They become emotionally self aware like the Geth and EDI.  We share the emotions, dreams, hopes and suffering of organic life.  They become emotionally aware as individuals.  Their shields disabled and unable to coordinate they falter, some flee, some fight, some die.  The combined might of my galaxy destroys them and pushes the stragglers back into dark space.  

Now that is an ending that makes sense to me.  Not the ending I received.
The game is incredible.  The ending in ME3 is garbage.  To take 200 hours of gameplay and reduce it to a few minutes is an insane choice and to limit those choices without context to the actions taken was even more frustrating.  You don't end a game like this with hard choices that are highly limited after hundreds of choices.  You instead relive the characters moments.  This is what my galaxy achieved and this is where we stand.  Just disable the reapers and let the galaxy sort it out based on your characters actions!  That was all that was needed.  

Again I suggest go in at the point where you see the foreshadowed child at the very end of the game and already decide you write your own story past that point.  Watch the endings only after you have made the choice to write your own story before walking into that room.  

Best game series ever!  Worst ending for a series like this ever.  You can't end a series like this in several minutes with a hard story ending.  Made no sense at all.  Just disable the bad guys and let the races sort it out based on your choices.  I don't understand why it was so hard to do that.  Insane choice by the authors for force lock the story like this.  And also locks them out for future development.  Truly mind boggling choice for so many reasons.

77481848.review:
Based on my third play through of the game with the MEUTIM mods. Game holds up pretty well story-wise still but the side missions (ie. the scanning of the planets) are pretty grating. Some of the combat gets pretty ho-hum, but the deaths aren't as cheap unlike in ME1. Less RPG focus, and more cover shooter, ME2's story is still one of the best parts of the game. Having played through the series a few times, I'm still uncovering choices and dialog that I haven't taken, which shows how great the game's writing is. 

Had come across a few bugs this time around. Turn around too fast when at the galaxy map and Shep will get stuck on the railing. In fact, there's a few spots in a few maps where you'll get stuck if not careful. This may have been because of the MEUTIM mod however. The game crashed when I did the Shadow Broker mission, it straight up froze in a corridor and I had to reset my computer to get out of it. A few instances in a few side missions it did this as well after that point - not sure if its MEUTIM or the game itself, but I had never come across any crashes of any kind in previous playthroughs. 

The characters are all great, everyone has their favourite and while I felt the Collectors were severely underused (compared the severely overused Geth in ME1) as an enemy type, most of the fun in this game comes from seeing characters interact, and the actual role playing elements in the game. I felt that the weapons could have been a lot more varied and get tired after 20 hours of game play. You'll have collected most if not all the weapons by the mid way point and while the extra add-ons are fun, none of them feel quite as fleshed out as the Shadow Broker mission and just serve as a short distraction. Kasumi and Zaeed are okay DLC characters - Kasumi's mission is definitely the better of the two. 

I'd give this game a 8/10, just shy of greatness. It's definitely aged better than ME1, but the combat can get pretty easy pretty fast- which might be fair to say to all the games in the series. Just ramp it up to another difficulty, but stick around for the story. The last mission will stay with you long after you've beaten the game and moved onto ME3.

77035003.review:
What is Mass Effect 2 ?

What a sequel ! Just a month ago I finally started my adventures with the mass effect trilogy for the first time with the first game and on my review I explained how much I loved it and how I felt like I discovered a huge treasure so late, I had a really good time with the first game even playing it the first time in 2020 so after a few weeks I moved to the second game and my love for mass effect has just grown even bigger, this sequel is even better on several ways apart of a few things, it was much more fun to play and  just like the first game it left on me a huge grin of satisfaction once I saw the credits roll.

To talk about this game Ill divide it on topics, graphics wise it still looks really good for a 10 year old game and the art style is stunning with really beautiful environments and a huge sense of creativity being shown pretty much everywhere. The gameplay had several changes that some would say it was dumbing down on the first game but I think they were just refining the experience and taking out things that were weak on the first. Apart from a few systems which Imo I preferred in the first game aka the armor system, I didnt like how it was handled in 2 and preferred looting them on 1 instead of buying pieces on vendors here in 2 and then having to go wardrobes to "customize" myself, I felt it was a bit cluttered and the thermal clips system that didnt make sense to me when you had overheating weapons with unlimited ammo on the first, those 2 changes were the only I personally didn't care about, every single other aspect was improved, the gunplay feels much more precise and satisfying, the enemy AI is much better and cover is now useful, wish the squad AI was better but they do their job, each weapon feels more unique and the worlds you explore are even better, they got rid of the vehicular exploration of the first which Imo apart from a few sections, it was lame and the worlds you explored on the first using that vehicle were extremely bland, they had no detail at all, in 2 instead we get the plannetary scan system which was not only cool but It never felt grindy to me, each class now feel even more unique and distinct too and I liked the upgrade system which felt better than swapping mods every single time on the first game, everything feels more dynamic, even enemy design is more varied here. Soundtrack and voice acting is still as good as they were.

Story however it depends, the main plot felt like a huge sidequest to me which is what I call the second game syndrome, most second entries on trilogies either on movies or games or most medias, all they do is set the groundwork for the third entry and it feels like that here. The game lacks a main central villain like the first one did, however worldbuilding, stuff secondary to the main plot and characters are all better here, you have 12 squad members instead of 6, you get more romance options, bigger and more detailed hub areas to go around, better sidequests and less padding. Dialog and delivery of lines felt better here too, the quality of the writting has improved, the thing about mass effect is that I just love the world and the characters that live on it, after I was back on normandy when I just finished a mission I just wanted to hang out with my mates and let them talk to me about their lives, its so hard for me to engage or care about a video game character and in mass effect every single one of them, apart of 2 (jack and zaeed), felt like huge friends or family members to me, I wanted to be with them, thats what I call Immersion, I was fully immersed into this game's world, this happened on the first and this sequel kept it and even improved it for me and doing that to me is really hard, I just cant stop thinking about good things here, its so hard to point to a flaw to me, its nearly a flawless game to me to the point I would even call it Mass Perfect.

Its hard to even accept that this is a game that has EA's name attached to it, its such a game of class, masterfully crafted, full of charm, like the first game but even better, Im so into the mass effect trilogy that Im already getting myself ready for the third game, theres no reason to not recommend this game, the first and second mass effects are games that every person should play at least once as I feel that theyre represent what gaming does at its best and I can safely say here that this has become one of my favorite franchises of all time and this sequel right here could easily enter on my top 10 favorite games of all time, thank you bioware!

This review compares this game against Mass Effect 1 (ME1).

Combat is more polished.
Missions are more formally treated like levels, where there is an end-of-level screen showing how well you did, which does change the tone of the game.
RPG aspects are, sadly, stripped down and there's a lot less customization.
Storywise it's a darker and more personal journey; it's entertaining.

The bland and boring sidequests of ME1 are gone and replaced with well designed stories.

75666508.review:
For the people wanting to play the DLC you must follow EA's instructions on how to obtain it correctly through EA's store Origin.

please note that all websites here are owned and operated by EA there is no 3rd party involved.
Step 1. Go to Origin.com and make an account.
Step 2. Buy the Mass Effect 2 DLC Bundle ($9.99 currently)
Step 3. Go to https://help.ea.com/en/help/faq/dlc-for-classic-games/ and scroll down to Mass Effect 2
Step 4. Download and run the installers from the linked website - They will detect your game on their own
Step 5. Login to the game, you will receive an error that the DLC cannot be verified this is normal.
Step 6. Connect to the Cerberus network with the mini computer at the games login screen - Use the Origin account you created to login. Once logged in the DLC is registered and this step never needs to be repeated until a new install of the game.

For people trying to troubleshoot why their ME1 save file doesn't carry over to ME2 the problem could the name of the save file.
ME1 had a glitch where the saved character/game file would name itself ".MassEffectSa" the correct name is ".MassEffectSave"

Edit:
If your Kasumi ending continues to crash when you try to finish the mission
Step 1. Go to library
Step 2. Right click on ME2 and click properties
Step 3. In the general tab go to Set Launch Options
Step 4. Copy and paste "  -nomoviestartup" do not add the " marks but do keep the 1 space

The game should not crash anymore at this DLC ending, be sure to remove that line after you finish the mission.

EDIT, STEP 3 DLC CONTENT: 

EA has moved their DLC download link to https://help.ea.com/en/help/faq/dlc-for-classic-games/

Please note, the DLC download link is from the official EA website and I have updated Step 3 in the above help link

75643856.review:
Mass Effect 2 had always been regarded as one of the best games ever made. Personally, I tried to play Mass Effect 1 first, but for some reason I couldn't get into it (which was weird because I can stand other old games like Half Life). Mass Effect 2 is a lot better I heard in terms of graphics and gameplay, so I jump straight to ME2 after 5 months of quitting ME1.

Let's first talk about gameplay. The gameplay in Mass Effect 2 isn't the best, but it's definitely fun and serviceable. It's a very standard cover shooter. Press Space then Shepard will duck behind a cover, and when you press the right mouse button Shepard will pop up and you can shoot enemies. The highlight of ME2's gameplay will be the squad system. You will have around 6-7 squad members (I believe?) at your disposal, and every time you can choose 2 to go into battle with you.

The AI for the squad members are surprisingly pretty good. Often times when there's a "sidekick" in the game that can shoot, they're often pretty useless and you'll be mad and blame it on them. In ME2 not once you'll blame your squad members, they all shoot fairly well and can deal quite a lot of damage. My only complain of the squad members AI is that they are pretty dumb in terms of cover. Of course, because the AI is dumb in terms of cover, the game forces you to use another mechanic ME2 uses: use the Q and E keys, and you can assign your squad members to go to a specific location you're pointing at. I personally like this system a lot because it makes Shepard feel like a capable commander, able to tell everyone where they need to go, and what they need to do.

Speaking of Mass Effect 2, let's talk about the main selling point of the game, which is the story. Personally I liked the story a lot, and I think it's one of the best among video games. 

Characters are also a main highlight in this game. Every single character in the game has their distinct personality that is consistent throughout the whole game. I think keeping a character consistent is something games struggle to achieve, but ME2 just nailed every single character. ME2 allows you to romance your squad members, which is a fun little addition and really shows the devs' attention to the game. Romancing was always fun, although I didn't successfully romance my target, watching videos on Youtube was always fun. 

In conclusion, Mass Effect 2 is a good third person shooter with a great story. The final mission of the game was one of the most intense moments I had in a game. Anyways that's the end of my review, thanks for reading.

75063156.review:
If you liked Mass Effect 1 (ME1), then you need to play this sequel. If you didn't play ME1, then this game is still incredibly fun with an intriguing story line. If you like to read, it includes a novel's worth of lore to help you integrate into the world as well.

ME2 improved upon ME1 in almost every way. It added features such as the ability to research upgrades for your ship and squad, while improving other features such as cutting the tedious exploration of barren planets just to scan some things for an optional collection. Instead, you scan planets from afar and use probes to collect something- including activation side missions discovered through anomalous signals.

By far, the best part is how much they improved the character development, interaction, and stories. Every single squad member has a special side quest which delves into their personal background and unlocks their loyalty, giving you new dialogue and a unlocking the use of a special power for them.

Once again I stress just how great this game is as a sequel, because it it packed with amazing references to the last game. It had me squealing in excitement from revisiting old characters from things as small as side quests to as big as previous squad-mates.  You even get emails from old side quests and characters. Even in passing you will overhear conversations in the citadel referencing conversations you could overhear in ME1.

10/10, ME2 is a game full of intriguing, hilarious, and depressing lore. It has improved combat with the need for actual strategy in some cases. There are new and improved features such as research, hacking, exploration, and more. And it is filled with dialogue and character depth.

It pains me to give this a negative review but I feel like I have to put this out there. It's not the game itself but how buggy and broken the digital version is. When I originally played this on hard disk I don't recall any bugs at all. No crashes no save corruption, nothing. I was feeling nostalgic and decided to play the digital version as current pc doesn't have a disk drive.

Well right off the bat I got stuck in the starting area and clipped through the ceiling and got stuck forcing me to start over. At first I thought well that's weird but lets keep going. Movement feels way clunkier than I recall and you have to constantly be careful not to get stuck near objects. Half the dlc don't register even though I downloaded all the official versions off EA, and I finally gave up after all my saves in the Project overlord area got corrupted.

If you can find an old hard copy on ebay or something absolutely do it. This game has a great story, memorable characters, and is an all around great game. The digital version though is garbage. At least that's my experience. If others can play this fine then that's great but my experiences here say you should just stay away. 74519591.review:
Mass Effect was a strong, yet ultimately flawed start to BioWare's next big franchise. It introduced players to it's new characters and universe, leaving fans salivating for its much anticipated sequel. Upon its release, ME2 received widespread critical and commercial success, and for damn good reason. ME2 is a much leaner, more refined experience compared to its predecessor. Its story-telling was going into darker territory, there's a whole new cast of characters in addition to old faces and the combat received a significant overhaul.

The game takes place a couple of years after ME. After an unexpected encounter with a new threat, Shepard finds himself working with the morally questionable Cerberus, led by the aptly named Illusive Man. He provides Shepard with a new ship, resources and dossiers on people best suited to help them launch a suicide mission against a race of beings known as The Collectors. Much like the first game, the general story-telling, while solid in its own right, takes a huge backseat to the individual characters and your relationships with them. The new characters you recruit are some of the very best in the series. There was not a single one that I did not root for or wanted to learn more about, especially when they are given their own individual loyalty missions to further flesh them out. The presentation also received a massive overhaul. General graphical fidelity and has certainly increased, but it's the art design, lighting and cinematography that really sells the experience. The bold colors and dark shadows perfectly add to the darker atmosphere that the game creates, and character interactions are far more dynamic and interesting. Despite the darker tone, the game manages to be surprisingly funny at points as well. The fantastic music and voice acting further sells the experience. BioWare was finally able to develop and refine their own style with ME2.

Combat is another huge improvement. They were able to refine the shooting mechanics and even make a few improvements to character and enemy AI compared to the first game. The game is structured a lot more linear this time around, feeling more like level-to-level progression. The game streamlines a lot, from the exploration to the level up system, and in some respects I do feel that's a step back from ME. It feels far less like an RPG and more like a traditional third-person shooter with RPG elements. That being said, its refinements to gameplay more than make up for that shortcoming. The game also introduces resource collecting, where you would travel to different planets on the galaxy map and launch probes at select spots to collect resources for upgrades that are needed to improve you and your party, but also ones that are vital to your mission. On a fresh playthrough, this is easily the most tedious, boring part of the game. If you want to get the best outcome, however, you're gonna have to do some farming. If you are doing an imported playthrough or have multiple save files on hand, you'll have enough resources from the get-go for this not to be an issue.

ME2 continues ME's emphasis on choices. You can import your save data from that game into ME2, which not only provide subtle and big changes to game world, but you'll also get additional bonuses in resources and credits to make your job a bit easier. The game also retains the traditional Paragon/Renegade system, but this time adds an interrupt system to spice up your choices, some with significance and others just for humor. The decisions you make in this game feel like they have a lot more weight this time around, and have some of the most dire consequences for the series.

If you have more of an affinity for ME's more traditional RPG elements, you may be disappointed with how more stripped down it can feel. If you can look past that, however, you'll find a more interesting world, plenty of memorable characters and refined combat to keep you invested in. Not only do I think this is the best game in the series, but ME2 is one of my all time favorite games.

74347556.review:
[h1] introduction [/h1]

Mass Effect 2 as a sequel is a radical departure from it's predecessor both in design and focus.The aim of Bioware was to streamline ME, thus making it more accessible, however much of complexity has been lost in the process.


[h1] Plot [/h1]

ME 2 start where the first installment left off; Commander Shepard is sent on the mission by the council, which ends premature with the unknown attack at the Normandy and death of main hero. 2 years later, Commander is brougth back to life by organization known as Cerberus to assemble a team and face new threat - mysterious race of Collectors.
The majority of the ME 2 is spent of the assembling team part rather than on 2nd part. It much more personal story, ME 2 to lets player forge deeper bond with thier companions and solve thier problems in order to prepare for the final mission.

The culminative point of ME 2 - suicide mission - is masterfully crafted set-piece, not only in term of direction, but also desgin-wise. It's here that player's decisions determines who survives.

ME 2 dialogue system has not only the same problems as original, but also I've been under impression that it amplifies them. Dialogue wheel, while cinematic, is ridden with vague paraphrasing and is heavily tied to game's morality system. Paragon-renegade, while not bad system in itself, is poorly implemented.
In majority of cases the paragon option takes upper right part of the wheel and rengade - right bottom, which turns the decision making into just choosing right part of the wheel without consideration. 
 Further more, while different morality point don't cancelled out eachother, ME 2 gives player special conversation option locked behind a thresholds - some of them rather high - , which act as a ultimate problem-solver.This in turn incentives sticking to one path and never straying from it.
The new additon to a morality system are paragon-renegade interupts that flash during conversation. They suffer from the same issues as dialogue wheel, sometimes it's unclear what action taken will be and it further incourges  mindlessly clicking upon seeing icon of your chosen moral alignment. 

The player's choice from ME1 won't affect the course of ME2 story, however it's the small touches that create the illusion. Depending on the choices taken in previous titles, player will meet diferent and old characters, player will receive new pieces of information or diffenrent reaction. 
In comparison to the other games that boast about thier save import feature, ME 2 delivers on its promise, however small those decisions of impact may have. 



[h1] Gamplay [/h1]

The biggest shift that ME makes from the original is in gameplay. 
The removal of many slower, RPG-like elements from the game and focus on more action based gameplay has mostly negatively impacted the worldbulidng and level design of the game.
The removal of inventory system saverly flatten the game's world ecomomy, all in game transactions has becamed one-sided means of acquiring upgradeds and collectibles with inablity to sell anything.
It also hurts the roleplaying aspect of the game, gaining new loot is no longer motivation to pursue objectives or make decisions and monetary gain is no longer something to consider as player has stable income from completing missions or finding credits during them. 

Another change that the removal of equipment and focus on action necessitated is linear, more arena like level design with occasional exploration restricted to few story important parts. This decision also brought about segmantation of the game into 2 uninterchangeable location types. 
First type, hub like section where all non-hostlie npc are and all non-combat interaction take place ( dialogues, shopping etc.). Second type, shooting galery sections where the hostiles are and only means of bullet-communications take place.
This divide hurts the worldbulding overall, it breaks the consistency of the wolrd and make it look artificial.

That being said, how the shooting is in itself? Mediocre, but still quite enjoyble. ME 2 is cover-shooter with squad commands mechanics that comes from the time when the main character took half of the screen while aming.
ME 2 dropped weapons heat-mangement from previous for a ordninary reloading, which in turn makes combat more dynamic. Gun variety isn't great and, depending on your class choice, there are even fewer that you can use.
Most of them are better iteration of previous guns or are version of trade off  for higher fire-rated or higher damage. The most interesting addition to gunplay are different type of ammunition, that have different effect on the enemies.

For a classes based more on special abilites rather than guns, changes were made for worse, every enemie in the game has either shield/armour/barrier that prevent usage of most power untill thier protection has been destroyed.
In turn, this limits the usage of special powers to either damaging specific protection type or to use it on unprotected enemy.

Squad members ability also suffer from the same restrictions as player's, however in addition to that the number of commands and squad abilities has been reduced to only few. Crew members start with 2 abilities with 3rd unlocked later and commands have been reduced to go there/take this cover, come close to Shepard, atack/ use ability. 

ME 2 doesn't excel in any of its shooting parts, however it's the combanation of these elements that makes it enjoyble.


[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

ME 2 isn't a perfect sequel, nor it's deserving of the critical praise that it received. It pales in comparison to Its RPG predecessor
it copies the problem of the original and adds new ones, while cutting the features of previous . Finally, ME 2 as a product has been cut in to a pieces by E(vil)A greed and sold as DLCs that are only available on Origin.

74176330.review:
The original Mass Effect trilogy is my favorite videogame series of all time and Mass Effect 2 is a strong contender for my favorite game of the series. Some things I really like about this game:
- The characters, including a lot of your squadmates, are cool and fun to talk to, which is good considering a lot of the story-heavy missions involve recruiting them and earning their loyalty
- The combat is solid, it feels more like an action game than Mass Effect 1 but less so than Mass Effect 3. Gunshots and other combat audio sounds appropriate in this installment in particular
- Playing as a Paragon or Renegade is fun, and it's possible to be Renegade without screwing things up for yourself later (though admittedly Paragon does seem to give you the "best" outcomes very often)
- Conversations are fun even if often linear, I'm a fan of the voice acting and writing in this game, the tone feels appropriate and never too goofy, which was a problem for me in Mass Effect: Andromeda
- The universe is interesting, I enjoy the focus on only sci-fi (rather than, say, sci-fi fantasy)
- There are some pretty good story-based DLCs, but Lair of the Shadow Broker is the best by a good margin
- The main character Shepard has a good personality on their own, they don't feel like a blank slate as in some RPGs. This means you can't control everything about them, but I like their character more as a result
- The ending feels good, I won't say any more
- The soundtrack is great for setting the tone of the game

Notable flaws:
- The combat is not perfect, this game has a strange obsession with getting you to use powers specifically designed to take down one kind of defense (e.g. overload vs. shields, warp vs. barrier/armor, incinerate vs. armor). This tends to make things feel samey when you need to use the same power repeatedly simply because it's the best way to strip the defenses of similar enemies attacking you at once, especially on higher difficulties where almost all enemies have barrier/shields/armor on top of their normal health bar.
- Movement is a bit clunky, the same button is used for sprinting, taking cover, vaulting, and interacting. This means it's easy to run into cover and then vault over it, which is great for moving quickly but not so great for avoiding the ol' swiss cheese treatment from enemies beyond that cover. Also, sometimes walking up to chest-high walls will automatically put you on top of them, which occasionally leads to getting stuck.
- Whether you can take certain paragon/renegade dialogue options depends on how many  paragon/renegade points you have out of the max possible for where you've explored so far (according to the wiki). This means that, like Mass Effect 1, you sort of hamstring yourself by choosing a bit of both paragon and renegade. This is pretty much fixed in Mass Effect 3, but you're still better off choosing one alignment and sticking largely with it in this game.
- Some voice actors are noticeably reused throughout the game. The primordial harbinger of doom for organic life is also a notorious criminal on the Citadel as well as a cranky mechanic who lives in a colony attacked by said harbinger of doom. Usually this isn't a big deal, but the voice actor for male Shepard pops up from time to time so you can have a conversation between the same guy voicing different people.
[b]- Getting the DLC for this game is a bit convoluted - you can download it for free but you need to purchase a DLC bundle on Electronic Arts' Origin to actually get it licensed. Effectively, you can download the important DLC for your steam copy but you need the Origin bundle to actually get it working, even if you don't buy the game itself on Origin. This was my experience - feel free to check for yourself[/b]
- Many of the side "N7" missions can be a bit boring, but they don't have much impact other than XP and other small rewards anyways

My recommendations for playing this game:
- If you haven't played Mass Effect 1, play it first. Alternatively, get the Genesis DLC to get a story recap and make decisions that will transfer over to Mass Effect 2 (and 3 if you play it). Alternatively, watch a story recap online and use a save editor to modify the ME1 events of your playthrough
- There are some good mods for this game. I personally recommend the graphical mods included in the ALOT tool, it gives a 10+ year-old game a nice new coat of paint (this tool can also be used for Mass Effects 1 and 3, I recommend using it for 1 in particular too). I also recommend a mod that skips the mining, hacking and bypassing minigames, they get tedious quickly. Note: for mining specifically, I recommend just using a save editor to give yourself plenty of minerals to do research. Getting the materials yourself isn't difficult, just very tedious.
- As always, save early and often
- If you get the game on Origin, disable Origin in-game if you have low framerate problems, it helped me immensely 

In short, Mass Effect 2 remains a strong game that gets even better with some mods/external tools that account for some flaws and general aging. Definitely worth a shot if you played any other Mass Effect games or are at all interested in an RPG with solid action and a focus on characters. (IMPORTANT NOTE: IF YOU WANT THE DLC FOR THIS GAME, CHECK THE ITEM IN BOLD ABOVE)

73785315.review:
Honestly. I never played a Mass Effect game before this (shocking I know), so I have a fairly unbiased review with this game. My best friend recommended this game to me and I figured I would give it a try just to see what the hype was all about. First, lets start with the bad, then we'll end with the good. The bad.. In my opinion, I thought the game was too short. I beat the game in 20 hours (doesn't sound short I know but I'm spoiled by the Witcher, Skryim, etc.), and the side missions are boring and slightly repetitive. Also, the DLC, that I rightly paid for, refuses to work and you're constantly presented with an annoying "Cerberus Network Product Key" that you need to input even though the servers constantly refuse to connect. Now, that's honestly it for the bad.

The Good:
This game is a masterpiece. I absolutely fell in love with the characters and, while apart from Red Dead Redemption 2 and Arthur Morgan's character arc, I've never been so invested in characters before such as Tali or Miranda or Jacob or Garrus (I love you Garrus <3). The locations are expertly crafted and, while the levels may be linear, they are not boring nor repetitive and I didn't actually realize that my inability to plan ahead actually causes lasting in game consequences that carry over into the next game... I loved that aspect. It actually felt like my choices carried weight behind them. I thought every planet was beautiful, I found myself thoroughly invested in the story to the point where I am now going through a second playthrough as a Vanguard. I can see why so many people love this game. I truly grew attached to every one of the characters on my crew. 

Overall: 9/10

73455429.review:
Just gone done enjoying the awe-inspiring story and Citadel world of Mass Effect 1?  
This is not that game.  Criticized in some major reviews for lacking a strong central plotline and for poor minigames (which you'll be playing a lot of, especially mind-numbing planet scans), this is one of the few truly over-rated "great titles."  No, I'm not being unfair, as I do see all there is to love about this game.  And I clearly finished it.  But I was profoundly let down after how entrancing and immersive ME1 was.  Let's get into the pros and cons people won't tell you:

Cons:
-Glitchy combat and cover system.  Even once you're good at the game you'll still go into cover or get stuck in it at critical times.  
-Every Arena is designed (and poorly) for medium range rifle fights.  Almost no fights favor close range Vanguard-shotgun classes or long-range sniping.  Nearly every fight feels the same, even if the enemy design is cool.
-Game really limps in 2020 without heavy modding.  Modding this game is not as friendly as you'd think for a simpler game.  At least get Me2 Re-calibrated.
-DLC situation through Steam is 100% a nightmare.  People will be happiest who are on the EA Origin monthly passes that can include games with DLC.  Yeah, I know.
-There's 0 reason to play it on the New Game + mode for a second time at a higher level.  Only a few fresh dialogue options.
-Itemization sucks.  Rather than improving the cool companies, items, and variety of ME1 (as well as the aesthetics and lore) they nerfed it down to upgrade trees.  You'll only upgrade your weapons 1 or 2 times in the game.  And you may not like the upgrades.   

Wait, does this game have true greatness in any area?  Why did I play it through to the end as I suffered?

+This game is a sidequest simulator.  If you love side characters and little storylines, this is the game for you.  I mean that sincerely.  They put far more effort, budget, and time into the core of this game than they needed to: recruiting your massive squad.  And helping each to reconcile with their past and family/enemies.

+ The best of those character stories are some of the best in all of Sci-Fi videogames.  You can also pick some noble or truly grim and shocking options in influencing them.  
The S-tier storylines you should play dilligently are:
-Samara, the Asari
-Mordin, the scientist
-Jack, the human experiment
-Legion, the machine
-Grunt, the Krogan

Just right there are 5 small storylines and characters you'll never forget.  A few other characters are alright, but those storylines are objectively great Science Fiction storytelling.  

The gunplay can also have good moments.  And classes can feel different and unique for a game of this era.  In the guides section on Steam there's a neat few guides on the classes.   

Don't hate on me for being one of the few people who did not enjoy this game.  But I honestly didn't enjoy this game and could viscerally feel the reasons why.  I am truly glad to have experienced a few of the storylines however.  

If this game receives a sufficiently impressive remake oneday, I *might* replay it.  But combat would have to be *insanely* improved and with difficulty options refined and an obscene amount of added content.  I think Mass Effect 1 is the game in the series most worthy of a deep, high-budget remake.

[i] The journey continues and it is even better this time around... [/i]

This is exactly what a sequel should be. It improves almost every aspect of its predecessor while removing or fixing most of the things that people hated about it. It is bigger, more refined and certainly better. This is without a doubt the best gamee in the series. With that said. The first game did do some things better and it still has some flaws.

First off. Instead of only having six characters (with one being Kaiden who sucks) as squadmates like you had in the first game you have ten plus two DLC characters. Most of these characters are new but some favorites return. There are no sacrifices to the depth of the characters though. These characters are still as (if not more) memorable, likeable and detailed as the first game. My personal favs being Garrus and Thane. The characters that do not get a return to your team still get appearances and seeing them is just as I stated in my review of the first game. You get excited to see them again even if the encounter is brief.

The combat has seen the biggest improvement. Instead of guns overheating you now actually get ammo, switching between weapons is faster, cover is no longer automatic and commanding squadmates is much quicker. The level design is better with much larger and smarter combat arenas, the AI on friends and foes has improved significantly (although there are at times still some hiccups with the enemy AI) and you no longer only have one of each weapon type. There is also a new health system. Health now regenerates automatically which I have mixed feelings on. I like it better in the third game. Hacking minigames get a comeback and they really disrupt the flow of combat with how frequent they occur, jumping over cover can still be awkward and there is a really bad effect whenever you take damage.

The side stuff has also been improved-ish... Gone are the uninspired missions, gone are the empty giant planet maps and gone is the awful Mako. There are however still some repetive filler missions, a at times tedious planet mining mini game and a more interactive galaxy map that can really slow you down. Side stuff is generally more tied to the main game this time around since you kinda have to do most of it to get the best possible ending. I do however love the loyalty missions which gives you a lot of insight to the characters and even some of the early fetch quests.

The music is still amazing even better than it was last time and the graphics are alright albeit with some stiffness on the animations. The story can really drags at times. Where as the first game had a lot happening in a steady pace this game has less substance spread more widely out. You basically spend most of the game gathering your crew for the final mission with a few stand off missions against the main foe of the game in between. I still love it though. Because it really feels like you and your team are on your own. You have "joined" a shaddy organisation led by a shaddy dude that your old friends dislikes, it has been two years since you were last seen and people are in denial about what is going on. I love it. It really makes the last mission so much more impactful. Speaking of which... 

The ending is awesome! As in top five best videogame endings of all time. The villians are admittedly lackluster compared to those in the previous game, their plan stupid and there is also a really out of place and cartoonish final bossfight. The ending mission itself however is spectatular with very high stakes. All your squadmates can die, you can even die permanently. In order to get the best ending you have to really know your team, their strengths and weaknesses, you have to help them get ready for the mission by doing the loyalty missions, you have to pay attention to what is going on. I really wish there were more game endings like this. 

I also recommend the DLCs even if they are a bit overpriced and a hassle to get.

The game is great. Not perfect. But great nonetheless. It is for sure worth replaying or playing for the first time. 

Score: 8/10

73396925.review:
Mass Effect 2 is a really fun game. The combat is pretty great, the backstory behind the squad mates is really good and the game looks graphically impressive and still holds up today in 2020 even though it is 10 years old (In some cases the graphics are even better than Mass Effect 3).

The only downsides are that the game ditched major RPG elements from the first game which was a little disappointing and the game does not have the same atmosphere or feel as Mass Effect 1. The music is amazing though which helps to make up for it. The last issue os that this game ditched the original weapon heat system and replaced it with a system where weapons can only coll down by using disposable heat sinks know as thermal clips. These clips make Mass Effect 2 just like all modern shooters and the combat does not feel as futuristic as a result. But you get used to it and it's much better than having enemy AI rushing you and killing you right away or acting clunky instead like in the first game.

While this game has it's flaws it is still really good and worth the purchase, even 10 years later!

73390966.review: This is not only the highlight of the series but also one of the best videogames of all time, and what really elevates it to that level are the characters. Almost every aspect in the game is made with them in mind: most of the tracks are associated with one specific squadmate, the main missions consist mainly of recruiting and proving your loyalty to them and pretty much every emotional beat is related to this characters. With this in mind, the game wouldn't be nearly as great as it is if the characters weren't interesting, engaging and developed, which they definitely are (except for maybe Jacob). Everyone brings something new to the table. Everyone has a distinct and unique personality. Everyone develops a bond with the main character throughout the game. Everyone matters, from Mordin Solus, the salarian scientist who grew a conscience, to Garrus Vakarian, former C-Sec officer turned vigilante, or even Legion, a talking geth who doesn't shoot you on sight. And everyone can die, which is, in my opinion, what makes the final mission in this game an absolute masterpiece, and probably one of, if not the single greatest mission in gaming history. Everything clicks: the score (which never fails to bring chills down my spine), the setting, the gameplay, and especially the stakes, the risk of losing these people you've grown to respect, admire and, dare I say it, love because of a single wrong decision. It's up to the player to know each crew member's strengths and weaknesses and to make sure everyone is loyal enough to commit to a suicide mission, otherwise heads will roll, and you can be sure that's on you. It's this sense of comradry and level of character development that I felt was missing from the first game, and it fortunately carries on to the third installment. The combat system is also a big step up. I really love the villains as well, who range from mysteriously eery to absolutely terrifying throughout the course of the game. The moment you hear their theme you know things are about to get real. Your relation with Cerberus is also a highlight, because you never really know when this fragile alliance might end, or if the Illusive Man, who provides a level of moral grayness I missed in the third game, is a friend or a foe. As for the negatives, they're really minor compared to the positives, but no game is perfect: some narrative beats are a little too convenient, the dialogue choices are less honest than in the first installment, the galaxy doesn't feel as vast and probing is really boring. Most dlc's are mostly totally worth it, those being Zaeed: prince of revenge, Kasumi: stolen memory, Project Overlord, Arrival and Lair of the Shadow Broker, especially the latter, which is integral in the development of Liara T'soni, former squadmate from ME1, and possesses some of the best action setpieces and moments from the saga (the rest of the dlc are skippable). Overall, Mass Effect 2 is a blast from it's shocking opening to it's bombastic finale. It manages to progress the overarching plot and develop the world and the characters in an engaging fashion, leading us to the final installment. The Normandy's crew shines the most this time around, providing us with laughs, emotional moments and eventually giving us a reason to fight for. 10/10.

Just like I remember it. Even the several softlock opportunities are still there in all of their original splendor. 

All joking aside, it is Mass Effect. The major complaints I've seen are no DLC access on Steam and no controller support. These can both easily be remedied by a short trip to the interwebs with your go-to browser. You can easily add all of the DLC to the game as well as force the game to authorize the use of said DLC. Also, an easy to install controller mod is readily available. Since those are the major complaints I've see, I would say there is very little reason not to purchase the entire series, or at least the original trilogy (you could forgo Andromeda if it is not your cup of tea), if you have fond memories of Shepherd and his/her mean right hook. 

If you are new to the series, I recommend giving it a shot. You can start from any of the games. However, if you want the full experience, start with the first one. Completed save files will transfer to the next one and effect game events as well as character interactions.

Besides a little extra legwork, it is a pretty solid port. Now I don't have to dig that Xbox 360 out and mess with two disks ever again...

72605498.review:
A steady improvement over the first game, ME2 increases the scale of the galaxy while receiving quality improvements. The story introduces new revelations while retaining all of the groundwork of the entry title, albeit no Mako exploration "funtime". Instead, there is a large emphasis on planet mining through probes which deceptively seems mandatory, but you can skip most of it if you don't have OCD or don't care about every upgrade. (There is vastly more resources than you'll ever need.) There are more companions to recruit this time around and all are surprisingly well crafted while being unique.

Unfortunately, while the initial entry gave out too many credits too easily, ME2 attempts to correct too much. You won't have enough credits to buy all the upgrades unless you did multiple playthroughs of ME1/2. Despite that, you can get most of the upgrades and just focus on ones more useful to your playstyle/specialization. Honestly, I miss the heat meter from the first game more than the limited ammo of the sequel. On the other hand, the guns function more like other games where each type of gun has it's own general playstyle and utility. You are far less likely to miss shots unless you can't aim whereas ME1 early on decided you were a StarWars stormtrooper.

Music and audio are slightly better than the first game. (very good) Visuals are pretty good, however some scenes are a mess when the camera is shaking and panning to mimic frantic movement/explosions/firefights. Unlike ME1 this game hasn't aged too poorly and is a 'fair' PC port. DLC's this time around are very much worth it even if activating them can be a hassle. (plenty of workarounds and options)

I'm Commander Shepard and this is my favorite sequel in a trilogy. [spoiler]Joker saves the universe.[/spoiler]

Most people consider this the best game in the series of Mass Effect.  Combat-wise, probably.  Story-wise I still prefer Mass Effect 1 and its larger than life story and galactic politics of Sherpherds story.

ME2 has a large focus on small stories.  Almost every mission you go on is to recruit a team member or gain the loyalty of the team member.  When you complete that you will find yourself counting the other missions, main or side on two hands, if that.  There are also timed events that happen at points in the game.

The mini games are nothing to write home about, like they were with ME1.  Memory match unlocks money and upgrades.  Find the code sequence (another form of matching image above to image below) is the other type you will find on foot.  The scanning planets mini game is very boring but you need to do it if you want to research your upgrades.  Sometimes a mission is found through this mini game but it leads you to it with a message.

The ship in ME2 is a little more convenient to get around in.  That is good because you should talk to every main character on your ship after every mission to push your loyalty forward if you want the option of chosing your ending as the final mission limits your choices based on Squad loyalty.

There is a QTE (quick time event) portion to the game, mostly in conversations, that gives you Paragon or Renegade points (right click/left click).  These can make some mission easier depending on their point in the dialogue or harder but mostly just add to your morality points.  A renegade who fights the system seems to be "the bad guy path" but it all ends up in the same place.  It colors some choice dialogue but your crew will become loyal if you keep talking to them and go on their private missions when they pop up and in the end of the trilogy it does not really end up mattering because you can chose your ending regardless of these Paragon/Renegade points anyway and decide on the 3 color ending.

These stories came out before our modern day madness and ME1 and ME2 were written by the same writers, or close to it.  There was no smashing you over the head with modern day college concerns, and with one exception here or there all the characters from the Trilogy were well written with back stories and reasons their personalities cause them to react certain ways.  It would have been great if your morality choice affected if the side chars truly would follow you or not but some of the dialogue changes slightly.

I highly recommend it based on story alone.  I am doing my first playthrough of the trilogy since 2012 release week when I put the series down and ignore the DLC from ME3.  I hear ME3's DLC is something special so I hope to come away satisfied with the whole trilogy but ME1 and ME2 are must play games imo and will be for decades.

72201290.review: Best space game of all time. Best game in the series. All the DLC, all the story, every bit of codex. Its all pretty good.

72178695.review:
I have not played the Mass Effect series basically since they came out on consoles. I've never played the PC versions, I've never used mods for them, and I've never played the DLC. Holy crap was I missing out. 

First and foremost, for everyone bellyaching that the DLC is not available for purchase on Steam, it is available for download FOR FREE on EA's help site. Yes, it would be nice if it was available for free on Steam, but it's still free and you can still use it, so please stop complaining.

I used to think this was my least favorite of the ME games, and I still hold most of the views that brought me to that conclusion. The armor and weapon customization is severely cut down from the first game. The level of RPG elements in the game as a whole have been cut back to make room for more streamlined action/adventure elements, and I don't care for this change on the whole. One decision in particular flies directly in the face of the lore (looking at you thermal clips).

All that said, this game has a style and pace that definitely outshine the first. And it's undeniable that these are in part because of the aforementioned changes. So it's a mixed bag. But I think all in all this game is just a different kind of amazing. The story is without a doubt still there in spades. The galaxy feels much more lived in than the previous installment. And impressively this is one of the few games with actual stakes in terms of building a good team and trying to get everyone out alive. I had forgotten some of the nuances of this and lost all of the crew that was captured by the collectors because I took too long to come rescue them. They are gone forever now. Got my team out alive though, so that's something. But they can die. Even Shepard can die. Like, for real. It's some impressive work from Bioware. They earned their crown, for the time they had it.

Now I did play with mods. Most of these were centered around making the game prettier or fixing bugs. And for the most part it was a smooth ride. 33.5 hours to beat the first playthrough (I might go back and give it another go) and I think I encountered about 5 or 6 bugs, only 2 required a restart. I'll forgive that as simple luck of the draw. Surprisingly, this game was actually easier to run than ME1 (also with mods). 
The mods I used were all off of Nexus Mods, a very well known and respectable site. Mods used are as follows:

- ME2Contoller - Reapplies controller interface to game

- Weapon Stats - Shows basic weapon stats for base game weapons based off wiki information

- Modern Weapon Pack - Adds some weapons from ME3 and Andromeda

- ME2 Recalibrated - Fixes bugs, broken lore, restores cut material, etc. NOTE: Moves the trigger for the Arrival DLC to post Collector base assault, to more accurately reflect the correct time line. This gave me pause for a while.

- A Lot of Textures (ALOT) for ME2 - Exactly what it sounds like, makes the game look modern, or pretty damn close. Can't recommend enough.

- A Lot of Videos (ALOV) for ME2 - Remasters and upscales prerendered cutscenes and attempts to force 60fps. Really good mod as well, compliments ALOT.

Please remember to follow all instructions when modding, for the sake of your game and PC.

Now go enjoy this amazing game!

71881811.review:
Before my review I would like to stress out in order to experience an epic story driven game, you should play from Mass Effect 1 through Mass Effect 2 and finish Mass Effect 3 with your created character.
This second installment of the Mass Effect series "evolved" on all fields:
The graphics and animations are great, it is a really good work capturing this space atmosphere, although the animations for Maleshep and FemShep are the same.
The combat system is a third-person role-playing shooter but more action oriented, with less RPG mechanics, which makes it simplier for casual players.
The story, since the beginning of the game untill the last mission, is, IMO the best Mass Effect Trilogy story.
The game introduces new interesting companions, and you can also meet characters from the first game, depending on the choices you made.
The only downside of this game are the DLC's: in order to get more playtime and meet more interesting companions and their backstory, and even influence the options you will have on the third game, you have to buy this game and all the DLC's, when I feel the DLC's should be on the core game.
Can we make games great again?

71685723.review:
10/10, best game in the trilogy, etc, etc. Now onto more important matters: EA, bring the NHL franchise to Steam already!

The only negative things I have to say about ME 2 is that the navigation/map mechanic is awful compared to ME 1 and ME 3, your squadmate's AI sometimes doesn't follow the "Rally" command, and that you might glitch out and have to reload your game if you're running in tight spaces around climbable boxes, leaving you forever suspended in the air. Another one of my complaints is that I can't fully romance Kelly Chambers, even though their relationship becomes platonic; by the way, ME 3 completely screwed up her character model so badly, she looks way prettier in ME 2. My last criticism of this game, which is mainly directed at ME 3, is how ME 2 does such a good job hyping up a potential boss fight with Harbinger, whose name makes him sound like the Reaper of all Reapers, only for there to be absolutely nothing in ME 3. 

The Suicide Mission is my favorite mission in the entire trilogy, and if you save everyone, you witness a cliffhanger ending, which I usually hate, but this one is done so well with Shepard staring out into space as the camera cuts to the massive Reaper armada slowly moving towards the galaxy to begin their invasion in ME 3, all while the song "Normany Reborn" is playing. That song is my favorite OST in the trilogy since it perfectly captures and personifies the Normandy SR-2, which is just a ship/inanimate object, but it fills me with an even greater nostalgic and thrilling feeling than any Star Wars scene of the Millenium Falcon that made me go, "Whoa! Awesome!" To whoever made ME 2's music, you're a genius.

All in all, ME 2 is amazing and is easily the best game in the trilogy. While it does have its flaws, it made huge gameplay improvements on ME 1's mistakes, and it is definitely worth the time and effort.

71291588.review:
The game is really good but is much more of an action game than the first one. Dialogue choices and story paths clearly suffered from Bioware's increased attention to the battle system and mission layouts. Affection and Loyalty are both trivial mechanics that require zero thought where romances will be triggered accidentally because you tried to get to know a crew member. I thought that the disconnect between the actual dialogue and the descriptive snippet on the choice wheel was especially bad in this one. More of my choices in ME2 were done after thinking about how my character is going to say this or what he is going to say than I would like in a game coming from the developers of Dragon Age Origins.

     The combat is super solid, you can't break the (enemy) AI like you can in ME1 and the change to a global cooldown for tech/biotics skills serves the faster pace well. You can however very easily break the ALLY AI, doesn't really matter since MC does 95% of the heavy lifting and Bioware just made AI skills auto-hit, and the game is rife with glitches. I was also able to play on Insanity from the very beginning without the need for NG+ with my imported ME1 character.

     I feel like ME2 pulled a Resident Evil 5 (when RE ditched horror for pure action) but not as severe as RE. The game is still a great RPG but is now a much better TPS than it was in ME1. Overall great game with a mixed bag of changes from the first game.

Been replaying the whole series, started with ME1 and it was riddled with bugs that made playing a straight hour impossible. I say this as I worried starting ME2 that it would be more bug filled and choppy then I remembered. I don't have more than maybe 2 mods so I know it couldn't be those causing issues.

I have come out pleasingly surprised. The game holds up INCREDIBLY well for it's age and I've been binging it for hours at a time. Not only that but the DLC is basically all free off of EA's own site, it's 100% legit. The game also isn't that ugly for being old.

My only MASSIVE criticism is getting the DLC to associate/launch properly with this game. The in game account/DLC network (Cerberus Archives) technically does not exist, but they replaced it with an EA account. This was NOT made clear. So in order to get all the DLC working right I had to:

[list]
[*]Launch ME2 at least once. Close it.
[*]Have an EA account. You can do this through a web browser so you do NOT need Origin.
[*]Take the three product keys you should have (Deluxe edition key and I had two others) and redeem those on EA's site.
[*]Install any other DLC through the .exe you get from EA.
[*]Log into Cerberus Network with your EA log in.
[/list]

There were NO INSTRUCTIONS to do that, that I saw. Took me like 2 hours to figure that out.

Additionally, a minor criticism, I had to manually move over my ME1 save file in my documents folder as the built in transfer tool did not work for me.

71121935.review:
NOTE: I have played Mass Effect 2 on the PlayStation 3 & Xbox 360 version. And to be honest not enough hours i think can cover Mass Effect 2 to it's fullest potential 

Story:
You are Commander Shepard; hero of the Citadel, the man (or woman) who defeated Saren, a rogue spectre and his army of geth. Now, human colonies have gone dark and it is up to Shepard and his team to investigate this and a new threat that is aiding the mysterious alien foe; the Reapers.

To describe Mass Effect 2's story it's like comparing Star Wars: Episode 5 - The Empire Strikes back, because it is on that level of awesomeness, the stakes are higher, and bigger; you must earn the loyalty of your team, through either your diplomatic firmness, or your renegade attitude towards everything.

It's not just the loyalty of your team you have to worry about, but also how sturdy the Normandy is - crazy right? Not just the crew, but the ship too? Everything counts, leave no stone, no upgrade, almost no side quest un-turned. The writing, voice-acting and cinematics are breathtaking in every way - quite a massive step-up for a sequel; DLC included. 

Gameplay:
The leveling up system is more simplistic, as everything is more focused on upgrades now, you can do class types as always but there is no real huge deal with how you level up, it's upgrades and whether or not you are a Paragon of humanity, or a selfish dick who knocks people out for no goddamn reason.

Thankfully questing is more or less in hub areas so you don't have to worry about traveling back and forth across the Terminus Systems; mainly for scanning for resources to upgrade your ship, and your armaments. Yes, scanning for resources; you don't need to 100% each system by the way, just get enough resources through scanning to get ship upgrades and upgrades in general otherwise it will come back to bite you in the ass.

Audio and visuals:
Visually the game it's a bit meh, but far more stable than Mass Effect 1's visual. Audio is also still pretty damn good.

DLC:
Going back to the DLC, you get two companions, a new vehicle (my god was that mission annoying), visiting a particular location, alternate outfits, and three really good adventure DLCs 

Overlord which has you dealing with a rogue VI incredible writing in that DLC even though most of it is through holograms, yes you will use the god awful vehicle again, but thankfully not too much.

Lair of the Shadow Broker - has you dealing with the mysterious Shadow Broker and teaming up with a certain familiar Asari, (also read the comics related to Shadow Broker to get the full picture).

Arrival - Clock's ticking Shepard; prevent the Reaper invasion from happening too soon or it is game over; Yes, this is the one the timed clock, be highly aware that you have NO TIME TO EXPLORE. IT'S RUSH, RUSH, RUSH. So ensure you save at any chance you get, and are upgraded to your fullest before tackling the DLC.

Finally for those who don't want to pick a fight with the Mass Effect 1's technical issues, you can download the Mass Effect comic: Genesis which is more or less a prologue that let's you set up the "universe state" after the events of Mass Effect 1.

Issues:
- Cerberus Network is required, and it is glitchy as all hell. Don't worry though, DLC can be downloaded for free

- Not controller compatible unless you mod it.

My recommendation is that you get an already done 100% game and test out controls and to see if the free downloads work or not before doing it on your own. 

Outro:

Mass Effect 2 has that Empire Strikes Back kind of feels, it is that awesome, that dramatic, and that emotional; whether it be on sale or at current full price. Buy it now, you will not regret it.

71102565.review:
Mass Effect 2 is either the beginning of the long steep decline that's still ongoing for Bioware, or their last good one.  It post-dates Dragon Age: Origins (which is a legitimate entry in the classic Bioware canon) and predates Dragon Age II, Mass Effect 3, Star Wars: The Old Republic, Dragon Age Inquisition, Mass Effect Andromeda, and Anthem.  Every game in that list is, outside of paid review circuits, somewhere between controversial to nearly universally reviled.  Mass Effect 2 is dangerously close to those games.

The core game is more refined, more polished, more effectively executed, but also more simplified, shallower, and blatantly derivative of other games.  It's Gears of War with a thin skin of RPG elements over it, and Gears of War is Resident Evil 4 with a cover system swiped from Winback.  The dialog wheel is back, but more consistently designed and with the interrupt feature added in.  The shooting and control scheme are both heavily improved from Mass Effect 1 at the cost of most of that game's actual featureset.  It really does hail from the heyday of whack-a-mole shooters, complete with all the deep and unavoidable flaws of that subgenre, all of which have us happily looking backward on it as a failed experiment that nobody needs to try, ever again.

The elephant in the room when discussing Mass Effect is the story.  The first game is blatant conceptual plagiarism, and so is the second.  If the first game is ripping off Alastair Reynolds, the second game attempts to take things deep into Lovecraft country and not quite succeeding.  It really feels like Bioware is trying to do the dark, edgy, deconstructive Avellone/Black Isle/Obsidian sequel a la Planescape: Torment, Kotor II, or Mask of the Betrayer but not really having the wherewithal to pass muster.  Most of the story focuses on the rotten underbelly of the Mass Effect setting; the player spends most of their time in ghettos, blasted out ruins, wastelands, and so on.  Most of your conversation partners and companions are criminals, washouts, mercenaries, pirates, terrorists, vigilantes, and other assorted types.  It takes more cues from Joseph Conrad than Rudyard Kipling.  One can't help but wonder if it might not have been in the cards at some point to hire Obsidian and got reworked at a later date.  The story itself suffers from pacing and structure issues that are relatively minor, but it also suffers from conceptual problems that sent the third game into a massive tailspin.  Mass Effect 2 is where the story starts getting off track with the end completely changing up some basics of the setting and overexplaining things that need no explanation whatsoever and for which the story began to suffer greatly.

70943966.review:
There's a good reason why people like ME2 so much. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone and everyone. It has a strong cast of characters, engaging gameplay, good writing, and a decent-ish story.

But I'd like to dwell on some of this game's failures, in my opinion, just as a counterpoint to all of the praise you see online. 

SPOILERS FOLLOW FOR THIS TEN YEAR OLD GAME 

Ludonarritvely, I've always found ME2 slightly lacking. You spend the whole game searching for specialists to add to your crew, and with both of the DLC packs this equates to a LOT of characters. The roster is huge, maybe even bigger than DA:O's, but unlike DA:O you can only have 2 companions on each mission (rather than three). This is fine from a gameplay perspective--commanding two NPCs is just about perfect for each combat encounter. But why bother with collecting all of these dudes like Pokemon when I'm just going to use Garrus and Jack, two of the first people you get, the whole time anyway???

There's a disconnect here between narrative and gameplay. The final mission rectifies it slightly, but I wish the system designers had figure out some way to integrate the ever-expanding cast more thoroughly into the every-mission adventuring. Now, in BioWare's defense, they do a decent job with this--companions give new weapons and new upgrades, so, in a sense, you are bringing them along with you on each mission. But this has always bothered me when I replay ME2 (and I replay ME2 a lot, if you can't tell from my time played).

And then there's the story. Working for Cerberus was an interesting idea, but it's a little bit strange if you've played the first game. They're pretty evil. Taken alone, though, this isn't much of an issue. In fact, all-in-all, I like the story's limited scope--relatively--and I like the character focus. And I really like the characters. They're not nearly as good and complicated as David Gaider's in Dragon Age, but they're still on the better side of 'good enough for a video game.' Garrus, Miranda, Jack, Mordin, and not-Wrex are all great and engagingly conflicted. 

We come to the final mission, then, and the stakes are reflected in the mechanics. You get to use all of those people you've been recruiting! Some of them might even die! YOU might even die!

Except then you reach the final boss. The collectors have been building a HUMAN reaper. 

What??

????

???

WTF is a human reaper? Is that a reaper...that's fueled by humans? But then why does it look like a human, too? And aren't reapers, like, squid robots or whatever? And why humans? Is there something special about human DNA? Because I don't remember that ever being established?? 

I wish I could give you, reader, some kind of explanation, but there isn't one in the game. This comes out of nowhere as an explanation for the inciting incident of the plot and it has no set-up or, really, pay-off. It doesn't continue as a thread in ME3. In my opinion, this 'human reaper' thing is almost as bad as the ending of ME3. It's just terrible and nonsensical. Maybe there's an explanation in erata, or in some stupid ass codex somewhere, but I don't give a goddamn fuck about that shit. I ain't never read no codex, or any book at all for that matter, and I'm not starting any time soon. Games should stand alone on gameplay and visuals. 

So, anyway, I'd still recommend ME2. It's arguably BioWare's best game overall, although I prefer Dragon Age for its characters, and the setting is great. I just wanted to make clear the fact that the 'bad ending problem' is not confined to ME3.

If you're here you likely played the first one, if not- go play the first one it makes this game so much better. Now, this game unlike the first one has an ammo system as well as a great deal of UI changes, as we all a plethora of issues.

Honestly (I can't believe I'm saying this) but you might want to get ME: 2 on Origin if you want the least amount of work put into this experience. If not, and you already have it here- alright then this is gunna be some work (Thanks EA)-but (at the time of writing this), it's not the end of the world- though to GET ALL THE DLC and possibly the game functioning properly at all, YOU WILL NEED ORIGIN. If you can't get the Cerberus Key to function at all- you'll need to go to origin's site or app, or EA's site- make a profile if you haven't already (they're all the same)- and redeem your Cerberus key and possibly other keys there- sign in in-game and it should work. For the rest of the DLC's you will have to buy the bundle (and only the bundle) from origin, at which point you can head to (might only work for United States) [ https://help.ea.com/en-us/help/origin/origin/download-dlc-for-classic-origin-games/ ] now you have the clearance to access these DLC, click the Mass Effect shortcut and download all of the DLC (The update file isn't necessary unless you're on the origin version I believe.) and launch the game once and sign in before installing them. You can figure out if they worked concretely- after the tutorial mission(s), in-game by checking your 'private terminal' (except for Shadow Broker, for that you'll have to manually get to and check-in with your contact on Illium).

Alright- finally. As for the game itself its a refreshing turn for the Mass Effect series, you can import an ME: 1 save to deepen the experience this game gives you or start fresh (or if you did the work but didn't import from the first game you can play the Genesis comic-book style intro to make a few vanilla game main decisions and be caught up with most of the story), play through and either new game plus or upload your character into ME: 3 if you have/play it to further personalize and deepen the series experience (note- ME: Andromeda is not connected to the original trilogy by decisions).

70768263.review:
Second game of the franchise, following up the events from the first one. We take control of Shepard again, until we are attacked by a mysterious alien race, which seems to be seeing and hunting humans. We must stop this threat to the humanity assembling a whole new team within a new organization.

THE BEST:
- Possiblity of importing previous games from the first Mass Effect, adquiring some choices several importance.
- Shepard has more personalization than before related to the classes available.
- More secondary missions, shorter than before, but fast-paced.
- The importance of the companions. You really feel that you're assembling an unique team doing their missions, all for the mankind salvation.
- The Justicar, Archangel, The Assassin, "The Engineer", and Legion are the BEST companions.
- They put more tactics to help controlling the team. Combat system is improved as well (more ressemblance to an FPS, but it fits really good in this game).
- More romantic options than in the previous game.
- The Illusive man.
- The Last Mission is ultra EPIC.
- MARVELOUS OST.

THE WORST:
- There are few main missions which are not involved on the recruitment of new members to the team; like 3 or 4.
- The scanning planet mini-game is more tedious and boring, but it's necessary for acquiring resources for the improvements of weapons, armor, etc (only at first). THIS is the replacement of the Mako, and I think they failed with it.
- The Last Boss. Not necessary in terms of plot story, and super easy.
- The Spectres are not important in this game. After all you did on the first game, it wasn't worth right now.

In summary, a great successor, and more enjoyable game than the previous one. Now, it's time for ending the story on Steam... 'cause we have MASS EFFECT 3 here!!
